TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister be requesting the honourable member for Blaxland to submit himself to cross-examination by the Western Australian Royal Commission in order to give a full explanation of any activity on his part as Treasurer in the rescue of Rothwells in October 1987? If the former Treasurer refuses to so appear before the Royal Commission, what steps will the Prime Minister take to ensure that all actions of senior Government Ministers in relation to the Rothwells rescue are made public before the Royal Commission?

—I do not know of any even alleged action by Ministers, other than the allegation which was made in the Royal Commission last week that the then Treasurer had been informed in a phone call about some approach which had been made to Mr Holmes a Court. I cannot answer the question as to the Prime Minister's attitude to this. I will seek to obtain an answer from the Prime Minister and advise Senator Knowles as soon as possible. Let me say, however, that on the question of refusal to appear in reference to the former Treasurer, as Senator Knowles puts it, it is not, in the Government's view, sufficient for some allegation to be made in that Royal Commission which immediately produces some response.
—That is the Gareth line.

—I should have thought there was some difference-and Senator Durack should know this; he had a lot of fun earlier this year-between that situation and the situation alleged in Senator Knowles's question.
—This is evidence given on oath.

—It is an allegation made before the Royal Commission. There have been all sorts of allegations made before that Royal Commission which the Royal Commission itself will deal with, and it does not need any help from Senator Knowles.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in the Sunday Tasmanian of 8 September 1991 which stated that veterans' services were being downgraded by the introduction of a prescription charge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see an article in the Sunday Tasmanian which reported a Mr John Cleary making a statement-which, I am sure, was just deliberate mischief-making and has caused a lot of anxiety out in the veterans' community-about the fact that the Government does intend to introduce a prescription charge of $2.60 per prescription from 1 January 1992 in relation to repatriation benefit prescriptions.

ANSWER.PARA: What Mr Cleary failed to do was to point out that each of those veterans will receive every fortnight a payment of $5.20, which will be a pharmaceutical allowance added to their present entitlements. This will enable them to cover the cost of their prescriptions as they obtain them in the course of the year. If in the course of the year a particular veteran takes more prescriptions than would add up to $135, from that point onwards all those prescriptions are absolutely free.

From every point of view, a veteran obtaining a pharmaceutical product will be covered either by the $5.20 per fortnight pharmaceutical allowance or by the safety net provision which cuts in after the equivalent of $135 has been paid out for prescriptions. One has a situation where all veterans will be fully compensated for any payment they make in relation to prescriptions they obtain. So, far from downgrading services to veterans, the Government's care and support for those veterans who require pharmaceutical products is there indicated.

I think what emerges from this particular exercise is that either Mr Cleary has needlessly upset members of the veterans' community-particularly in Tasmania-or he knew in advance that what he was doing was mischievous and, in a political attempt, set out to destabilise the community of veterans in Tasmania.

Of course, the whole problem is whether Mr Cleary is acting as the national vice-president of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia or whether he is acting as a Liberal member of the State Parliament in Tasmania. He cannot decide which hat to wear. In the interests of veterans I would urge him to act in a more professional way rather than as a petty politician seeking to score a very easy political point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and refers to the Minister's constant complaints in this chamber about executive salaries and perks. Is the Minister aware that a former Keating staffer, Dr Edwards, received a termination pay-out of almost $80,000 after only four months on the job? On what basis did his Department advise that such a huge pay-out was appropriate? Does the Minister himself believe that this was a fair pay-out in the light of the termination conditions available to ordinary Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Kemp for acknowledging at last that I, on behalf of this Government, have been a rousing critic of the excessive level of executive remuneration in this country. At a time when wage and salary earners have been looking at wage growth per annum of around 6 per cent, as I recall it, on the statistics we are looking at executive salaries shooting ahead by anything between 12 and 20 per cent. In those circumstances, captains of Australian industry enjoining Australian workers to exercise wage restraint for the good of the country is an obscenity. I am glad that Senator Kemp at last has been prepared to recognise that advocacy by the Government. I trust that recognition will be followed by some action from the Opposition to join us in calling for the executive level of this community to exercise the same restraint that we are asking ordinary wage and salary earners to do.
—This is about termination pay.
—It is not about termination pay. If Senator Tambling had listened, he would know that the first part of the question is about executive remuneration.
—The question was about the severance payment.

—I am coming to that. The honourable senator should exercise some patience. Let me now turn to the question of severance payment to Dr Edwards. Although this is the first time that I have heard the figures that are set out in Senator Kemp's question, I do not in any way challenge their authenticity. I am not familiar with the contractual arrangements that were entered into by the former Treasurer and his most senior economic adviser. Of course, it is appropriate that the Treasurer of this country should seek the best economic talent available and write a contract which would remunerate that individual at a level that that individual would command elsewhere, either in academia or in the field that I understand Dr Edwards pursued for some while-as an economics commentator and journalist.

ANSWER.PARA: I am unaware of the actual terms of that arrangement. But I do know that for contracted consultants to Ministers, a termination criteria is written into the standard contract. If that contract is terminated before its due time-as I imagine it would have been in this case, given that the Treasurer resigned office before the completion of the parliamentary term-the normal contractual arrangements would apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is fairly clear that there are two classes of people in this country: one class are Labor's mates and the other class are ordinary Australian workers.
—The honourable senator will ask his supplementary question.

—I asked the Minister not whether the money was legally paid out-I have no doubt that it probably was legally paid out-but whether he thought it was fair that a man who has worked for this Government for only four months should receive a termination payout of $80,000. I further ask the Minister: is it correct that there will be an effective tax rate of only 5 per cent on this $80,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly I do not have the terms of the contract in these circumstances.
—Do you think it is fair? That is the question.

—If Senator Macdonald will just wait a few minutes, I may just come to that matter. If he wishes to interfere with my answer, I may choose not to come to that question. He can please himself. He should give me a chance to answer the question-in other words, he should be quiet-or I will deal with it in the way in which I want.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have the terms of the actual contract in front of me. The question I am being asked is whether it is fair. That suggests that perhaps Senator Kemp is arguing that a government should break a contract that it has is entered into and that the breaking of a contract would be a fair thing to do in particular circumstances. I would be interested to know under what circumstances Senator Kemp feels a contract entered into by a government ought to be able to be broken.

On the question of fairness, as I say, I do not know the terms of the contract. If it is true that Dr Edwards worked for the Treasurer for only four months, it is obvious to me that he may well have passed up the possibility of other appointments and that that is an element in the question of compensation in these circumstances.

I return to the fundamental point in this issue: what is a reasonable level of remuneration for the Government's most senior economics consultant; and what is, therefore, the most reasonable level of severance in the event of that contract being broken outside of the responsibility of that consultant. These are questions about what the particular rate for that level of position might be. They are not matters touching on the level of broad salary constraints, as they are being pretended to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I think I can help Senator Cook on this issue. I asked him whether he thought it was fair for someone to receive $80,000 after only four months work. That was the question.
—Order! There is no point of order, and you know that was not a point of order.
—Senator Kemp, who thinks he can help me in the answer, may know the answer. There is no way any information can penetrate a closed mind, and I therefore conclude my answer.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware that some major regional air services are in jeopardy while airlines promote frivolous frequent flier schemes for corporate bosses on major trunk routes? Will the Minister ask the airline industry, State governments and his own Department of Transport and Communications to guarantee that expenditure on lavish prizes is not offered at the expense of appropriate standards of regional air services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Reynolds's reasons for asking this question but, I am pleased to say, we do not actually have a form of government in this country that is sufficiently centralised to require airlines to moderate their commercial practices to that extent. The question of incentives that are offered by airlines to their fliers is very much a matter for the commercial judgment of those airlines, but it is important to the Government that regional air services are maintained at a healthy level.

ANSWER.PARA: In that respect, I was interested to note that, in the case of the rescheduling of Hazelton's routes in New South Wales and, I must say, the very welcome decision by the New South Wales Government to open up to deregulated competition those Hazelton routes over which the Government had a monopoly, only a matter of days-it did not take very long to happen-after the suspension of those Hazelton services 10 of the 14 ports vacated by Hazelton now have other operators operating air services which, in some cases, are direct from those ports to Sydney. It is very much a matter for the market to determine what incentives are offered to frequent fliers or, indeed, any other fliers who utilise the services of the airline.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In the light of the recent decision by the Premier of New South Wales to implement a four-year fixed term for the New South Wales Parliament, and given the very warm reception this has received in the media, the business community and the public alike, firstly, does the Government agree that a fixed term would be a sensible reform to the parliamentary process, thereby allowing for more long term government decision making and increased business confidence in a stable election-free political environment; and, secondly, will the Government give an undertaking to investigate proposed amendments to the Constitution for a four-year fixed term for the Federal Parliament? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sowada seems to be unaware of the Constitutional Centenary Conference, held in about April of this year, at which a very wide ranging discussion on constitutional reform was held by people representing many parts of the Australian community. I think the discussion was chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen, a former distinguished High Court judge and Governor-General.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that meeting, a unanimous view was expressed, as I recall, by that conference in support of a four-year term for the House of Representatives. I think there was less unanimity as to whether that should be a fixed term or just a maximum outer limit to which the House of Representatives could run. Of course, there are many more difficult questions on the relationship of terms of the House of Representatives to the terms of honourable senators: for example, whether honourable senators should have an eight-year fixed term. It is a very real question for which it would be, in my opinion, very difficult to secure support out in the community.

Senator Sowada also asks whether it would be a sensible reform. I think a sensible reform would be one which was so convincing to the community that it would engender sufficient support to have a majority of electors in a majority of States give their assent to that reform. That is a hurdle which Premier Greiner does not have to face in New South Wales in his constitutional reform; it just requires an Act of Parliament.

Therefore, in order to get the sort of support required for sensible reform, one would need to have certainly bipartisan support-and I know that the Prime Minister has held discussions with the Leader of the Opposition in this respect-and tripartite support from the Australian Democrats would be extremely desirable. I hope that all major parties-and indeed the Independents-in this place can be involved in any discussions which would lead to putting to the Australian people the question of the parliamentary term for this Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the United Kingdom which is led by the Rt Hon. Lord Thomas of Gwydir. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your time in Australia has been both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister noted criticism of the International Labour Organisation in some recent newspaper editorials? Do these criticisms demonstrate any knowledge of the ILO by the editors of these papers? Since the ILO is a United Nations agency and this is only the second time its world head has visited Australia, is the Minister surprised that none of the critical newspapers have sought to interview Mr Hansenne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed the criticism in some editorials. It seems that some editorial writers have simply swallowed the Liberal Party's propaganda line on the International Labour Organisation without in any sense checking for themselves to see the nature of this organisation. Some of the more bizarre implications in terms of editorial writing have been that the ILO is simply an international body of Labor parties or an international union body when, of course, the ILO is an agency of the United Nations, tripartite in nature. It is the longest running such agency, having been established under the old League of Nations in 1919.

ANSWER.PARA: The criticisms that I have seen go to the allegation that the ILO may not know about Australian industrial relations law. That may be something that entertains the back reaches of the minds of some editorial writers. It has some superficial appeal, one might say, given the unique system in this country of compulsory arbitration. But Australia has been a member of the ILO since it was first founded in 1919. The Australian Government has been an almost continuous member of the governing body of the ILO since it was reconstituted under the United Nations in 1946; there were only two gaps of one term each.

Australia has, through Sir Halford Cook-no relation of mine-presided over the governing body of the ILO. The Australian union movement, through its President, Mr Martin Ferguson; Australian employers, through the Chief Executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Bryan Noakes; and the Government are all currently members of the ILO governing body. That body is indeed well informed about circumstances in Australia. But under convention 87-the Freedom of Association Convention which this country adopted 18 years ago-we have been required by governments of both Liberal and Labor party persuasion to report annually to the ILO events and developments in Australia. Against that background, it is therefore idle to say that the ILO may not, as the editorial writer in the Melbourne Herald-Sun said on Friday, know enough about Australian industrial relations.

The most serious criticism that I have seen is that which supports the view expressed by Mr John Howard that he as a lawyer is entitled to criticise the Committee of Experts. It is simply one lawyer criticising the views and opinions of other lawyers. The Committee of Experts is a quasi-judicial body. Mr Howard is, after all, a suburban Sydney solicitor. Let us compare his qualifications to those of the 20 members of the Committee of Experts. Which countries do these eminent lawyers come from?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Speaking on behalf of the suburban lawyers.

—I am not, actually. I am not even speaking as a Melbourne barrister. This is an unpaid contribution, I might say. Senator Cook is attempting to disparage a member of the other House by referring to him as a suburban solicitor and, worse, he is somehow trying to assert the proposition that it is not right for a member of a profession to criticise other members of that profession. I would invite you, Mr President, to direct his attention to both of those facts and to insist that he not disparage a member of the other House in this manner.
—Order! In reply to the point of order, I did not consider the language to be unparliamentary.

—I have a particular advantage in not being a lawyer myself, but I know that what Mr Howard said was not to criticise the view of the Committee of Experts. He said that he disagreed with its view and that Australia should withdraw from the ILO. That is what Mr Howard said. It is like a government saying that, if it disagrees with the view of its supreme judicial body, we should sack those lawyers-we should sack the ILO if its view offends us. As a lawyer, Mr Howard should be someone who has some understanding of and respect for the law and the practice of it, and at least understand the fundamental principle of the separation of powers.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me turn to who and which countries constitute the 20 experts. The countries are-not all of them but just a sample-the United States of America, Italy, India, Poland, the USSR, the Federal Republic of Germany, Senegal, Finland, France, Singapore, the United Kingdom and Japan.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—It cannot be said that that sample of countries does not represent the whole spectrum of world opinion. Let me now turn to the qualifications. Eleven members of the 20 countries are professors of law at leading national universities in their own countries; six are chief justices of their own countries; and three are members of the International Court of Justice, one a vice-president, and one a former president of the International Court. They have unanimously made a clear finding that Australian industrial law is not in conformity with the Convention on Freedom of Association because there is no provision for the right to strike in the law of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: What stands before the community as clear as a pikestaff is that our law does not conform to international minimum standards and what is acceptable by the relevant United Nations agency as adjudged by a qualified panel of world ranking jurists. That is the question for Australia. For Mr Howard to be portrayed as simply one lawyer debating with other lawyers and the suggestion that that is therefore permissible is, I believe, quite a caricature of the current circumstances.

I conclude my answer by saying that in isolationist, introspective Australia this cannot be a matter which we simply debate among ourselves. Australia has been called to answer in the world community. In this region, more importantly than in other regions of the world, it is vital for a developed country such as ours to uphold minimum international standards lest those of our neighbours who are less inclined to do so take our example as an example for themselves to do something else.

This is a serious matter. The Australian Government will not be knee-jerked into pre-emptive action. We will cautiously, rationally and intelligently come to grips with the ruling of the ILO and, in consultation with employers and unions, make our decision known in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Minister in his answer referred to a certain ILO report. I ask that he table that report.
—This is a smart and seamy manoeuvre by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. He knows that this report was provided to the Government and was leaked into the public domain.
—Who leaked it?

—Certainly not this Government. Under the national labour consultative legislation which, I understand, is supported by the Opposition, the report is confidential to that body. The Leader of the Opposition now asks me to table the report. In those circumstances I decline to do so.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is that an appropriate answer?
—Yes.

—I did not ask for Senator Faulkner's view. The ILO report was selectively leaked. The Minister took up that leakage to his advantage in debate. He referred to it again today. Surely, as a matter of justice, apart from anything else, the Minister would want the whole of the report on the public record in order that it might be debated in its complete form.
—Order! It is up to the Minister as to whether he tables the document.
—What have you got to hide?
—Senator Crane, I do not need your advice constantly on how to run this chamber.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of newspaper reports which indicate that the SEC in Victoria pays the salaries of full time union officials? Does the Minister believe it is appropriate for Victorian power users to subsidise union activities? Are there any employees on the Commonwealth Government's payroll who are paid while acting as full time or part time union officials?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of newspaper reports to that effect. I am not aware of the veracity of those reports. I have not had an opportunity to check them. The SEC in Victoria is not a statutory authority that falls within the domain of the Commonwealth Government and, therefore, it is something over which I have no direct influence or control. Nonetheless, it is something to which my curiosity extends and normally it is something that I would check. I am in the process of asking for advice from the Victorian Government. It is entirely within its province as to whether it gives it. Indeed, I am not entirely certain as to whether it is in a position of authority to require it to be given by the SEC of Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know whether the veracity of the reports is substantiated, but I am aware of the reports. I do not consider it appropriate for governments or government authorities to pay the wages of full time union officials in any circumstances. However, if they are being asked to serve on bodies set up by the Government or those statutory authorities, for the time they are involved in serving the needs of the Government or the statutory authorities I do consider it appropriate that there are grounds for compensation or remuneration for loss of services to their organisations. That is a normal practice in all circumstances. If that is what is applying here, I can understand it. As I say, I am not in full possession of the information and nor is it reasonable to expect me to be in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr, President I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware of employees on the Commonwealth Government's payroll who are being paid whilst engaging in either full time or part time union activities, other than serving on boards-in other words, Commonwealth industrial matters?

—We do consult full time and part time union officials in various ways and at various levels in our Public Service. We believe that to be an appropriate and proper course of action. After all, they do represent the significant interests of our employees. We are a government given to consultation and working out problems by discussion. Without being able to give a figure, I am aware that we are constantly engaged in consultation. In terms of remuneration, I am not aware of any circumstance in which it can be said that the Commonwealth Government is paying the wages of full time union officials.
—Or part time.
—Or part time union officials.
—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise the Senate whether media speculation on the privatisation of Melbourne Airport is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The press articles that I have read, which presumably relate to a meeting that I held just recently with a Victorian Minister, are absolutely incorrect. I made it categorically clear that the Government will not be supporting any suggestion to privatise Melbourne Airport. I have also consistently said that the Federal Airports Corporation is more than happy to discuss with any proponent means of joint venturing or owning terminal facilities at the airport. That was communicated to the Victorian Government only a matter of days ago.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the Victorian Government-not the Committee for Melbourne-will be proposing to the Federal Airports Corporation that it investigate the feasibility of some private involvement in furthering the very substantial program of capital works which the FAC already has in train at Melbourne airport. That is completely in accordance with Federal Airports Corporation policy and has the full support of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that, like most other rural industries, returns for rice growers have been the lowest for the past 12 years. I also point out that rice growers have no tariff protection from imports into the domestic market. Is the Minister aware that 30 per cent of Australia's rice for consumption is now imported and that Thailand is the largest exporter of rice to Australia? Is the Minister also aware that, in contrast, a royal decree in Thailand bans Australian growers from exporting their rice to that country? Does the Government consider that this situation is indicative of a level playing field? If not, what action can the Government take to ensure that Australian rice growers are not further penalised by having one rule for them and another for foreign growers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just inquired of my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether this was more in his domain than mine so that the Government could give Senator Bjelke-Petersen a more authoritative answer in the circumstances. I am aware of the circumstances.
—You cannot talk authoritatively on much!
—I ask for that interjection to be withdrawn; it is a terrible slur.
—Do not ask me to judge on it!

—I am not aware of the royal decree that allegedly applies in Thailand to which Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred. I agree that it is not indicative of a level playing field; nor, it is sad to report, is the common agricultural policy of the EEC indicative of a level playing field. It is equally sad to report that the export enhancement program conducted by the United States, which enables its wheat to penetrate our markets at an uncompetitive rate enhanced by the taxpayers' dollar in the United States, is not indicative of a level playing field. It is sad to report that they are the circumstances that afflict our rural economy on the world stage at the present time.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is, of course, opposed to those types of artificial barriers-be they royal decrees, tariffs or other forms of non-tariff protection. That is why we have led the world in forming the Cairns group of countries to agitate in the GATT round against the protection that is afforded unfairly to particular countries against free and open trade in the world. That is why we will pursue, through that round and through other bilateral measures that we can take, the freeing up of world agricultural trade.

It is true that the quality and the cost competitiveness of many of Australia's rural products are far superior to those of other countries. If there were free trade, our rural community would be much more successful in penetrating markets than where free competition is not allowed and there are artificial impediments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's reply and the fact that he considers that there is not a level playing field in so many areas, can he inform the Senate why the Government has withdrawn tariffs on so many primary products?

—It would hardly seem appropriate for a country such as Australia to be arguing to world superpowers and others that the playing field should be level when we do not practice that principle. I think there has been a degree of bipartisanship in this period of parliamentary office in that there is a need for us to conduct ourselves in the world not only by word but by deed as well.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of concerns about the employment of New Zealand shearers in the Australian wool industry? What are the specific issues involved in the employment of New Zealand shearers in Australia? How is the Australian Government responding to the employment of New Zealand shearers in the Australian wool industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be my day.
—First the Eagles and then this.

—We all know that the Eagles will come good. One of Australia's most famous songs starts with the words, `Out on the boards the old shearer stands'. It is sadly true these days that, this season, fewer Australian shearers are standing out on the boards, and a number of shearers from New Zealand are standing in the stands where Australian shearers ought to be standing.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two reasons for this. One relates partly to the question I answered a moment ago which was asked by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I refer to the collapse of the world wool market and the fact that the Australian clip is down and, therefore, seasonal workers such as Australian shearers are not in such great demand.

The other reason is the apparent campaign sponsored by the National Farmers Federation to encourage the breaking down of the rates and conditions under the Federal shearing award, and the growth of quasi employees who are working on contrived contracts of employment under the pretence that they are not employees but are, indeed, contractors. That campaign is being conducted in rural Australia at the present time. Unfortunately, it is a campaign in which many of the economic refugees from New Zealand who face the harsh strictures of a high unemployment economy led by the New Zealand National Party are finding their way across the Tasman to Australia. They are prepared to accept those contracts against the background of no similar award protection in their country, and no tradition in our country in terms of the application of that award.

It is wrong to pick on the subcontractors simply because of their nationality. I do not. I think that unemployed workers in New Zealand are being exploited in those circumstances and being put against the interests of Australian workers. What I do criticise is the Australian employers who engage in those contrived employment practices and hire those workers in need, such as those New Zealanders, who then come in and break down conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I object to that.
—Senator Crane may object to it but, of course, he is wrong on so many other matters. Those workers break down the conditions that apply legally and properly in shearing sheds around this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Every small businessman in every wool town in Australia must also be concerned. Shearers make up a substantial part of the rural populations of country towns. If they are unable to get work because contractors are being brought in from outside those country towns, the local rural economy suffers grievously. There have been reports in the weekend press that this may lead to violence. Consistent with what I have always said, I would deplore that if it arose. However, one can understand the circumstances in which local shearers see sheds being populated by people brought in from outside the district to do work which they may have done, or traditionally expected to do, for the past 20 or 30 years.

My Department, through its awards management branch, will be conducting random inspections in country Australia to ensure that the conditions of the Federal shearing award are properly observed, that any contrived employment arrangements aimed at gypping Australian workers out of their jobs will be dealt with and that the proper observance of award rates, conditions and standards will be carried out by contractors in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. During Question Time last Thursday, with regard to Robe River, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: It has a record of defying orders made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disobeying.
—No. The Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: It has a record of defying orders made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
I ask the Minister to tell the Senate of the instances when Robe River has, in fact, defied an order of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and operated outside the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my answer last Thursday I referred to the case of the Seamen's Union of Australia and Cape Lambert Management Services, which went into voluntary liquidation after having had an adverse finding against it. A new company sponsored by Robe River then came into automatic effect. Its whole process of renegotiation with the Seamen's Union seemingly has now--
—You mean that they rearranged their affairs.
—I do mean that since 1989--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1989 Cape Lambert Management Services has been conducting a dispute with the Seamen's Union over employment conditions of tug crews at Cape Lambert. As I recall, there were eight appeals to the Full Bench of the Commission, including two appeals to the High Court. When that process was exhausted, Cape Lambert went into voluntary liquidation, setting at nought the progress made by the Seamen's Union. A new company then sprang up immediately and the whole process looks as if it will go through again. Just to complete the picture, I said that the Seamen's Union was threatening nationwide industrial action over that-one could understand the provocation that was being entered into against it-but I enjoined the Seamen's Union not to engage in such industrial action.

—I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to recent comments about noise in respect of the proposed third runway. Are the comments that have been made about this matter accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to say that they are grossly inaccurate, if they have been reported correctly. The reason that I am concerned about this is that the newspapers in which they have been published--
—Then sit down.

—Frankly, the issue is a little more serious than that and deserves to be canvassed. A great many people in Sydney are reading these reports and they will have concerns which, on the facts, are entirely unfounded, or expectations, unfortunately, which, on the facts, will not be realised. Mr Williams has been reported as saying that when the third runway is constructed at Sydney Airport 10,000 houses will be subjected to noise levels of 25 ANEF or greater because of the third--
—Which is absolutely baloney.

—Senator Brownhill is correct; it is absolute baloney. But he goes further and says that these houses will have to be acquired by the Government and demolished. He has put a figure of between $1 billion and $2 billion on this. He goes even further than that. He is reported as saying that the residents in these dwellings will have legal rights to have these houses acquired and demolished.

ANSWER.PARA: If Mr Williams is reported correctly, he has grossly misinterpreted the facts as contained in the draft environmental impact statement. The facts are that, as the EIS shows, the number of dwellings experiencing noise levels of 25 ANEF or greater will fall dramatically as a result of the construction of the third runway at Sydney airport from nearly 20,000 houses in the 1988 case to 9,705 in the year 2010. That is a net reduction in excess of 10,000 dwellings. Furthermore, of these 9,705 dwellings, the number of dwellings newly exposed to noise levels of 25 ANEF or greater as a result of the third runway is in the order of 2,300, which, I would suggest, is significantly fewer than the 10,000 claimed by Mr Williams.

The implication that Australian noise standards dictate that existing residential dwellings subjected to noise of 25 ANEF or greater have to be acquired and demolished by the Government, which Mr Williams is reported as saying, is also factually nonsense. The relevant standard-that is, Australian Standard 2021 1985-is regarded as a planning document for land use compatibility with aircraft noise in the construction of new dwellings and not existing dwellings, as claimed by Mr Williams.

Claims that the third runway will result in noise mitigation costs of up to $2 billion are therefore grossly exaggerated. These claims are significantly inflated by including residential dwelling acquisition and demolition costs in those figures, which will not be incurred. Press reports of insulation costs of $460m to $630m refer to the cost of insulation for all dwellings exposed to greater than 20 ANEF within the third runway area, including residences that are currently exposed to those noise levels or greater.

The draft EIS estimates costs for insulating residences newly exposed to noise greater than 20 ANEF to be somewhere between $170m to $230m. But there is an important point that has to be made: there is nothing whatever, in terms of the legalities of this, in government policy or in regulation which requires insulation of residences affected by aircraft noise. Therefore, the key assumptions that are used to support these statements by Mr Williams are fundamentally flawed. Issues concerning noise mitigation are being addressed by the environmental impact statement process.

In conclusion, might I say that the Government is pressing to the fullest extent the Federal Airports Corporation-the proponents of the third runway-and its consultants, Kinhills, to bring this process to a conclusion. I will be having a further meeting with the FAC and Kinhills on Wednesday of this week to once again raise this issue with them. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aquitaine Australia Minerals Pty Ltd was engaged in mineral exploration in the Great Victoria Desert of South Australia in the early 1980s under the South Australian Government's exploration licences. These licences included land on the margins of the Maralinga restricted area, known as section 400, which contains former British nuclear test sites controlled by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Some of this land was within the Woomera prohibited area of the Woomera rocket range controlled by the Department of Defence. Aquitaine obtained Defence Department approval for access to the Woomera prohibited area and approached the then Department of National Development and Energy for approval to construct an access road through the south-western corner of section 400 to exploration areas near Lake Dey Dey. Approval was given on the basis that all movements through the area would be notified in advance to the Australian Federal Police detachment at Maralinga village. Aquitaine was also permitted to locate survey points within section 400 under AFP supervision.

ANSWER.PARA: In April 1982 the Department was advised that Aquitaine had constructed a spur road from the Lake Dey Dey road to the north-east ending, approximately 10 kilometres from section 400. This road did not require the approval of the Department as it lay outside the test site area. Nevertheless, Aquitaine was asked to provide a map showing its location. In June 1982 the Department received a map showing roads constructed by Aquitaine.

This map was shown on a recent SBS Dateline program as evidence that Aquitaine had constructed a spur road into the Maralinga area and undertaken exploration in the area. Rather than showing that Aquitaine had penetrated Maralinga, as claimed by Dateline, the documentary evidence presented by the SBS show that the spur road, the drilling site located near the end of this road and a radiometric anomaly referred in the program lie outside the section 400 area. The SBS program does not document unauthorised activity by Aquitaine within the Maralinga section 400 area. On the other hand, there is clear evidence that Aquitaine, and a number of other mining companies, were involved in metal exploration in the region. There seems to be no cause for further investigation of this matter.
