TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Report of the Australian Human Rights Delegation to China, 14-26 July 1991 and I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am pleased to table the Report of the Australian Human Rights Delegation to China. The delegation, which visited China at my request from 14 to 26 July 1991, has produced an excellent report, detailed in content and fascinating in its insights, which will attract the attention of all those concerned with human rights in China. I warmly commend for their efforts the leader of the delegation, Senator Schacht, and the other members-Mr David Connolly, Senator Vicki Bourne, Professor Stephen Fitzgerald, Professor Alice Erh-Soon Tay, Mr Chris Sidoti, Dr Richard Rigby, Mr Kevin Garratt and, not least, the secretary, Mr Jon Sheppard. The expertise and professionalism of the delegation is illustrated not only in the report but also in the results achieved through this exercise.

Foremost of these results is the fact that a constructive and non-confrontational dialogue on human rights has been conducted to the satisfaction of both sides. In the course of the dialogue Australia's concerns on a range of human rights issues and on individual human rights cases have been clearly conveyed. It was pleasing to hear that the Chinese authorities accepted the representations made by the delegation on behalf of the Australian Government regarding a large number of prisoners of conscience, and that new information on several of these cases was provided.

At the same time, the delegation has listened carefully to Chinese perspectives on human rights and has gathered much useful information on the Chinese legal, judicial and penal systems. The delegation's report explores in some detail Chinese views on the importance of economic rights and the place of the individual in Chinese society. It examines the question of a state's right to restrict political and other fundamental freedoms, and the proposition that a state or a ruling party can interpret the will of the people and determine the collective good at the expense of the individual. The delegation has concluded that these arguments do not stack up against the principles enunciated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

I share that view. I believe not only that civil and political rights are equally important as economic, social and cultural rights, but also that the practice of individual freedoms in all these areas-with the physical and intellectual mobility and flexibility that involves-is, in fact, more likely than not to stimulate economic growth. I see no incompatibility between China's modernisation goals and granting greater individual freedoms to its citizens.

Regardless of these differing perspectives, the visit by the Australian delegation has advanced the principle of the universality of human rights. This is because, in accepting the visit and engaging in intensive dialogue, the Chinese Government has accepted that human rights has a legitimate place on the international agenda and is a proper subject for discourse in its bilateral relationships. This is a major step forward from China's defence of its actions against the Tiananmen demonstrators when it argued that its forceful response was purely an internal affair and, as such, not subject to international scrutiny. It is important that the Chinese Government should understand that the international community takes a different view and that its relationships with countries such as Australia will be affected by the way in which it treats its own people.

I am not suggesting that we should expect any sudden or dramatic changes as a result of the Australian delegation's visit. Neither I nor the Government at any stage had any illusions that the delegation's visit would achieve any dramatic or immediate changes in the present human rights environment, which is not a happy one. But we do believe that, by the range and quality of its contacts and the unprecedented nature of the dialogue which did take place, the delegation has made an important contribution to improving that climate in the longer run.

While there can be rapid change in a state's treatment of human rights-and we only need look to the Soviet Union as an example-we are prepared to work over the long term on encouraging changes within China and other countries. I am hopeful that the delegation's visit will contribute to a better understanding on the part of the Chinese authorities that there are alternative approaches to human rights issues and that there are advantages to adopting a more open and human attitude. I am encouraged by the delegation's conclusion that there are elements within the Chinese leadership and within its legal and judicial systems who appreciate that a less repressive social and political environment would enhance economic growth and stability.

I should also like to make the point that the dialogue that the delegation to China has embarked upon should be seen in the context of the Australian Government's overall approach to regional human rights issues. We are aware that differing perspectives on human rights in our region require understanding on Australia's part and a willingness to enter into discussions-not just declamatory condemnations. Our aim is, so far as possible, to avoid confrontation and to reach common ground from which there is a better prospect of achieving improvements in human rights. We should never lose sight of the fact that, in all our concern to make our voice and our values heard, improvement in human rights on the ground is always the basic objective.

As the delegation has done, the Australian Government bases its position on the rights and principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We believe that the universal observance of these principles would result in a more just international order from which the security and prosperity of all nations and individuals would benefit.

Let me now respond specifically to the recommendations in the delegation's report. It follows from all of this that the Government has no difficulty with the delegation's recommendation that the process of dialogue should continue. I am pleased to note that Vice Premier Zhu Rongji has expressed his Government's willingness to receive a further visit by the delegation, and this is a matter which we will, of course, follow up. The question of timing will be a matter of mutual convenience. Vice Premier Zhu has also accepted the Government's invitation to visit Australia, and arrangements for his visit are progressing. That is referred to in chapter 7 paragraph 18 of the recommendations.

The Government has likewise indicated its readiness to receive a visit to Australia by a Chinese human rights delegation. This was an integral part of the agreement for reciprocal visits reached between myself and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen last April. To date, we have not been approached by the Chinese on this matter. Chapter 7 paragraph 19 of the recommendations refers to this point.

The delegation has made a number of proposals on the further development of contacts between China and Australia in the human rights field. The Government will give careful consideration to the idea of training for Chinese judicial and security personnel and the possibility of further two-way exchanges. We hope that non-government organisations will also see fit to take action in this area. This is referred to in chapter 7 paragraph 21 of the recommendations.

As to the delegation's recommendation to continue exploring the establishment of a joint Australian-Chinese working group to act as a mechanism for on-going discussion on human rights issues, I agree that the idea has merit and that, although the Chinese side has rejected the proposal, we can look at it again as the dialogue develops. In the latter respect, I welcome Vice Premier Zhu Rongji's conclusion that the existing arrangement for reciprocal visits and the contacts established during the Australian delegation's visit constitute an open channel for further pursuing our mutual human rights interests. For its part, the Australian Government will certainly follow through on the representations taken up by the delegation in both Beijing and Lhasa, and will continue to press for information and express its concerns over individual human rights cases using these channels. Paragraph 20 in chapter 7 of the recommendations refers to this.

The Government will also continue to urge China to respect internationally accepted standards of human rights and to become a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. As a major world power, a member of the United Nations Security Council and a country which has identified itself as a leader of the Third World, China can play an important role with regard to international and regional human rights issues. Australia will encourage China to adopt a positive approach to such matters in international forums, including through our shared membership of the UN Commission on Human Rights.

While I have spoken of dialogue and cooperation, it is important to stress that Australia will not resile from its firm commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights in its relationship with China or, indeed, world wide. The delegation's report has highlighted a number of disturbing aspects of human rights in China. Australia will continue to take a close interest in these areas. We will, for instance, closely monitor the fate of prisoners of conscience- including those charged with various forms of political dissent-and will maintain our consistent position of opposition to capital punishment. This is covered in chapter 7 paragraphs 22 to 24 of the recommendations.

The Australian Government also shares the concerns expressed by the delegation over the human rights situation in Tibet. I have no difficulty in agreeing with the delegation that is desirable that there be discussions, without preconditions, between the Chinese Government and the Dalai Lama with a view to improving human rights conditions in Tibet. This is referred to in chapter 7, paragraph 27, of the recommendations.

I am conscious of the controversy and the scope for abuse in relation to China's family planning policies and again the Government and I share the delegation's concern over some aspects of the implementation of those policies. At the same time, it is important to recognise the immense problems facing China in terms of population growth, to which the delegation has itself drawn attention. We will give consideration to the delegation's recommendation for Australian assistance in this field. This is referred to in chapter 7, paragraph 25, of the recommendations.

The delegation has commented on Australia's policy of accepting international accountability in regard to our own human rights record. The Parliament can be assured that our open and frank approach in this regard will not change and indeed will very shortly be reinforced through our accession to the first optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, by which Australia will recognise the competence of the Human Rights Committee to receive complaints relating to Australia's obligations under that covenant. We will also not fail to respond as fully and directly as we can to the type of inquiries made to the delegation while it was in China.

On the particular issue of refunds to Chinese students enrolled for education in Australia, I have noted the case put to the delegation as reported. However, I should note that the Government has taken steps now to address the genuine hardships being faced by a number of students in China who lost fees prepaid to Australian colleges which have since closed. On 5 September, in a joint statement by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, who has policy responsibility in this area, and me, the Government announced that it would extend the eligibility date for acceptance of refund claims in relation to institutions where closure was attributable to Government measures to tighten entry requirements. This is referred to in chapter 7, paragraph 26, of the recommendations.

In conclusion, I once again congratulate the delegation on the successful completion of its task. I realise how difficult this exercise was for both sides, especially as we were both breaking new ground. The Australian delegation did not take any backward step in holding to its belief in the universality of fundamental human rights and did not shy away from asking difficult questions. At the same time, it made considerable progress in promoting human rights goals and demonstrated-it is worth saying again-how such a sensitive issue can be approached in a non-confrontational and constructive manner.

I also think it significant, in terms of our bilateral relationship, that this new form of contact should have been initiated between Australia and China. It should be a matter of some satisfaction for both sides that our bilateral relationship has the breadth and the maturity to accommodate such a dialogue. I look forward to its further development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I wish to respond in only a preliminary way as I have only just received the report. As the Opposition expressed some reservations about the concept of this delegation, I think it is important that I make some comment and put the report before us in that context. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) congratulated the delegation on the successful completion of its task. In a technical sense, no doubt, that is correct. It took the task; it went to China; it gathered some information within the limitations that the Chinese permitted; and it clearly promoted human rights goals. The real question is whether this delegation, other delegations and other means are, in fact, resulting in an improvement of the human rights position in China.

SPEECH.PARA: We recognise that the Australia-China relationship is an important relationship to Australia. Therefore, it is perhaps not easy for us to raise and press issues that might in some way have a detrimental effect upon other aspects of that relationship, perhaps economic or in other fields. Nevertheless, basic human rights according to the internationally accepted standard are so fundamentally important to us, so much a part of our basic values, that we would not be doing ourselves justice if we did not take every opportunity to press these issues upon a country which simply does not accept or comply with those minimum internationally accepted standards.

Regrettably, China is still in that category. Regrettably, when I look at reports of Amnesty International, reports of the United States State Department, in its annual report on human rights throughout the world, and reports of Asiawatch, it is difficult to see any significant improvement in human rights in China having occurred since the terrible events of the Tiananmen Square massacre. I guess that in some ways the only positive side is that China, despite continuing to press its point that human rights are an internal matter, is now for the first time accepting delegations that are visiting China for the purpose of discussing these issues. In fact, this delegation, as I understand it, commenced with an invitation from China.

On the one hand, if we believe that the opportunity to communicate, to develop a dialogue-to use the Minister's expression-is important if we are to influence a change of attitudes, we would have to say that that is a positive development. Our reservations were really as to the motivation of China in so inviting us and our fear that Australia may well be used as part of the most favoured nation debate that China was having with the United States. In other words, it was a fear that China would be able to promote to the United States, in particular, that its situation in human rights was being improved by the fact that it was prepared to invite and host international delegations to China.

We still do not know whether that initial reservation was well founded, but we decided in the end that the further opportunity to communicate our values-our values which are internationally accepted in this area-to the Chinese outweighed that risk, and that is why the Opposition parties supported this initiative. We are pleased that we were represented by Mr David Connolly, the honourable member for Bradfield, who is going to speak this afternoon in the other place on this report and give some further detail.

We supported the visit and the report is interesting and confirms some of our concerns. Clearly, it indicates that the delegation was able to communicate to Chinese authorities Australia's concerns and the generally held views within Australia. I think I can say that fairly. We regret that when the Opposition, through its leader, Dr Hewson, myself and others, last year visited China and put these concerns to China's leaders, our doing so was condemned by the Minister. We trust that his acceptance of China's invitation that we send a delegation indicates that he has changed his views as to the importance of a dialogue.

In fact, one might say that the major distinction is that we were able to put those views to authorities at a much higher level. It was in fact interesting that even though China's leaders put to us that human rights were purely an internal matter, they were nevertheless prepared to continue by arguing to us that the number of students being held post-Tiananmen was not what the international press claimed and also that Chinese students who had engaged in democracy demonstrations out of China could return to China without fear of prosecution. So, whilst on the one hand they claimed that this issue was purely internal, on the other hand they were prepared to debate it, indicating that even at that time they were starting to recognise that it was an issue that had wider international concern and was an issue that the international community would press.

There are a number of specific concerns that I want to mention. One of them is the information that is now coming out of the most recent visit of a delegation which, of course, was from the United States. It is worth nothing that since the Australian delegation there have been two further parliamentary delegations-one from France and the other from the United States. The US delegation, which visited China in the week prior to 4 September, was unfortunately barred from visiting imprisoned dissidents and claimed that the human rights position had worsened.

My particular concern, and the concern that I want to raise again today-as has been raised by others in recent times-is that of the health and welfare of the dissidents Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming who were both gaoled for 13 years for allegedly organising the demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. There have been recent reports that the two have been on a hunger strike, although this has been denied by the Chinese authorities. Wang was reportedly hospitalised in early September. His relatives claim that he is suffering from viral hepatitis and that he did not receive treatment for the disease while in prison. I have been unable to get any recent reports of his condition.

Members of the families of the prisoners told the US delegation that they were harassed, subjected to surveillance and deprived of the ability to make a living. These are serious allegations and concerns, and I trust that the Australian Government will be doing all within its capacity to raise those concerns with the Chinese authorities and press the fact that the imprisonment of these two dissidents-in accordance with the spirit, as I see it, of the delegation's report-does not meet fundamental internationally accepted human rights standards.

It is also interesting to note that when the British Prime Minister, John Major, during his recent visit to China, raised the issue of human rights with Chinese Premier Li Peng, he was given what is unfortunately something of a standard line by the Premier who argued that China had been bullied and humiliated over the past 100 years. There is no wish on the part of the international community to bully and humiliate China. In fact, we would argue that it is very much in China's best interests to meet these minimum human rights standards. If it did so, China would be much better accepted within the international community and it would be helped in all sorts of ways.

I was pleased-and I hope that the Australian Government will adopt a similar attitude-when Mr Major told a press conference at the end of his visit that the UK would maintain pressure on China in respect of human rights issues, saying that it was, `unrelieved, unremitting pressure that often gets results'. I mention that because some time ago the Australian Government, in our view, prematurely lifted its sanctions on aid to China. One must remember that those limitations on the relationship were imposed not only as a protest to the events that occurred at Tiananmen Square but also as an exercise to influence China to improve its human rights behaviour.

Mr Deputy President, in accordance with what I have put to you this afternoon, unfortunately that improvement has not occurred. Yet, the sanctions were lifted, which tends to indicate to the Chinese that they were not applied in a serious manner in the first instance. So I do hope that the Australian Government will join with others, such as the British Prime Minister, and maintain unremitting pressure upon China to at least get up to this minimally accepted human rights standard.

The only other issue that I wanted to touch upon, because it is current in this context of China's attitude to human rights, is the position of Hong Kong. Not surprisingly, the people of Hong Kong are nervous about the extent to which they will be able to maintain after 1997 their standard of human rights, which has been so much higher than that in China. It was worrying to us that after the Hong Kong legislature passed a Bill of Rights to try to protect Hong Kong once it loses the benefit of the common law, the message came from Beijing reminding Hong Kong that under the terms of the basic law the Chinese Government can review all pre-1997 legislation. The interpretation in Hong Kong was that the Chinese Government would not accept the protections that the Hong Kong legislature was trying to write in for basic human rights.

I hope that the international community will continue to maintain pressure to protect the human rights that Hong Kong has been able to achieve. In some small way, I make mention of the role that Senator Chapman will play next weekend on behalf of the Opposition parties here in Australia. He is leading an international observer mission to the Hong Kong elections. The democratic process, at least to the limited extent that will be permitted before 1997, is part of the very minimum protections that members of the Hong Kong community are looking for to sustain them in the years past 1997.

In conclusion, I pick up the notes of concern in the report about the position in Tibet. I guess that the disappointment by the Committee is fairly consistent with what I have said-that there are ongoing breaches of human rights beyond that which the international community can accept. I take this opportunity to urge the Australian Government to continue to apply what pressure it can upon China to improve its standard of behaviour in this regard. That will not only be in the best interests of Australia and the international community but also in the best interests of China itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the tabling by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) of the report of the Australian human rights delegation to China. Naturally, as leader of the delegation, I am pleased to be able to speak in this debate. I would like to say a few words in support of the Minister and the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very honoured to lead the delegation. In recent years I have been on a number of overseas delegations-both parliamentary and non-parliamentary. I have to say that this delegation was second to none in terms of the way in which its members went about their work. I believe that the delegation membership was, as the Minister has already mentioned, a very good balance between members of parliament, governmental officers and experts on China and Tibet. That enhanced the work of the delegation. It also meant that our Chinese hosts very quickly realised that they were dealing with a delegation that did contain considerable expertise on China.

This expertise was manifested in different ways. Three members of the delegation were fluent in Mandarin; one member of the delegation was fluent in Tibetan. All members of the delegation had a long interest in human rights issues in general. Specifically, they had a long interest in China and Tibet. It took only a matter of a day or so for our Chinese hosts to realise that it was not good enough just to have a standard form of meeting where a presentation would be made and then that would be the end of the discussion. As a result, in many of our formal meetings, the discussions went for two, three or 3 1/2 hours. The delegation often asked to have further meetings the next day to complete all the work on all the issues we wished to raise.

I think the Chinese were a bit surprised at some of the detailed knowledge the delegation already had. In particular, I think Professor Alice Tay knew more about the Chinese legal system and the Chinese constitution than did many of the officials with whom we had dialogue. That added greatly to the ability of the delegation to stick to the major points and to get answers from officials.

The delegation was criticised before we left for China to the effect that we would do nothing other than whitewash the situation there and would not be able to achieve much. The people who expected, just because we were visiting China, that prisoners would be released, laws would be immediately changed and so on were mistaken. Certainly, delegation members did not expect to achieve those things. We would have loved to have done so, but they were not in our normal expectation. We went there to achieve the beginning of a dialogue with China on human rights. The fact that the Minister was able to negotiate our visit with the Chinese authorities was the beginning of that dialogue.

During our two weeks in China we had lengthy discussions with a whole range of governmental officials. Although at times they were robust, frank and often argumentative discussions, I give due credit to the Chinese officials that they did not break off the discussions. They sat them out hour after hour as we hammered away on the points about human rights. I think that should be acknowledged in respect of the Chinese officials. They stuck out in the discussions when, I suspect, some of us believed that on a number of occasions they might easily have ended talks forthwith. But we were able to present to the Chinese officials individual cases of human rights abuses, which are well known and have been documented. More than 200 such cases were presented both in writing and-in individual cases-verbally. It was the first time, as we understood it, that any foreign delegation or foreign government had been given information on a number of those cases. We were given a promise that we would be given more information. We will have to chase up that matter as a Government, as a parliament and as a delegation so that the promise of further information should not be allowed to rest.

We raised with the Chinese the persistent issue of the death penalty and its use in China. It is the official policy of the Australian Government to oppose the death penalty. The raising of these issues at times created some tension and agitation with the Chinese officials. We consistently asked for information as to how many people had been executed in the calendar year 1990. In Beijing, this information was not forthcoming. It was basically denied to us on the ground that it was a state secret or on the ground that the bodies we were speaking to did not have the authority to release such information. Ironically, it was in Tibet, where one suspects there are the worst cases of human rights abuse, that we got an acknowledgment that in 1990 there were five death sentences given, two of which were carried out and three of which were under probation. None of the five cases was for political crimes or political dissent.

Questions asked about the Chinese legal system during the visit gave information to the delegation that indicated that the Chinese legal system in its concept, structure and operation is very deficient in terms of any definition that is adopted in a country such as Australia. Again, it was Professor Alice Tay who said that the Chinese legal system in its operation is about where Western Europe was a couple of hundred years ago. Notions of appeal and due process are just not in the system. One of the most interesting figures we received came from a defence lawyer. It should be noted that there have been defence lawyers in the Chinese legal system only in the last decade. A defence lawyer in Shanghai told us that there were 16,000 prosecutions last year in Shanghai and only 23 acquittals. That is a success rate for the prosecution that we in Australia would find unbelievable if it were to happen here. We also discovered from the same set of figures that fewer than half the people charged had access to a defence lawyer. Even when there is access to a defence lawyer, it happens only after a person is charged and not when first investigated. Such a person can be detained for long periods without having access to a lawyer.

Probably one of the quieter successes achieved by the delegation was that in these long discussions with Chinese officials, in raising these issues and questions as to how the system operated, we got them to start thinking about the weaknesses of their own system. Our impression from talking to defence lawyers-we were the first foreign delegation that had had the opportunity to have lengthy discussions with those lawyers in China-was that as they work the system they are becoming more keenly aware that there will have to be improvements in the structure of the law and due process. For example, a lawyers' association has now been formed, and one of its representations to the Chinese Government is to give people who are being investigated, and before being detained and charged, the right of access to a defence lawyer. I see that as a beginning of a process that we should enhance wherever we can. I hope that in the dialogue that proceeds in the intermediate future we can arrange for appropriate lawyers from Australia to go to work in China with defence lawyers and that we can invite defence lawyers from China to work with appropriate bodies in Australia to enable them to get used to dealing with a system that is more open and transparent in providing legal process than is the case in China.

As the Minister said and as is dealt with in our report, we looked at the family planning issue. Many questions have been raised in the West, and even in this chamber, about the operation of the Chinese family planning program. Certainly, there can be no argument but that it is a draconian program. The one-child policy and the financial penalties that are imposed if a family has more than one child are quite severe. This raises moral questions about the interference of the state in such private and intimate matters as family planning. When we were in Szechuan Province-one of the most populous of any in China, with 110 million people contained within an area about the size of Tasmania-it was made very clear to us by the officials, who were very open with us, that China has no choice. The effects of a policy involving no family planning would mean that within 30 or 40 years China's population would total some two billion, which would be catastrophic in its environmental and social impacts on its society. It would mean that the Chinese would not be able to improve the living standards of their own people, and that would lead to chaos in all its forms. Therefore, the argument put to us by the Chinese was that, draconian though the system is, they have no choice if they want to create a stable society.

Questions have been raised about the use of abortion in the family planning program. It is quite clear that the Chinese do not see abortion as the main means of family planning but as a last resort when other family planning methods fail. In Szechuan Province last year there were some two million births and 600,000 abortions. The evidence that we could see was that, overwhelmingly, those abortions resulted from the failure of the other contraceptive devices provided within the family planning program.

My own view-and I say this without equivocation-is that Australia should look to its bilateral aid program to providing assistance in a major way to the Chinese family planning program. We should provide assistance to improve the contraception that is available and information about it to the Chinese people. I am not an expert in contraception, but I have to say, looking at the locally produced IUDs that are available to Chinese women, which involve a steel ring, my impression was that they looked more like torture weapons than devices for the prevention of conception.

As Senator Vicki Bourne, a member of our delegation, said, the issue of family planning in China is really an issue of women's health and it should be seen in that light. Therefore, it is quite justifiable for Australia, with our modern technology and modern medical system, to be able to provide advice to the Chinese on the issue of family planning.

Tibet was a very sad episode of our visit. I do not think any of us expected that the circumstances of the Tibetan people would be as bad as those we saw when we were there. The Tibetan people are clearly unhappy with present governmental arrangements. It is clear that an overwhelming majority-I have said previously in press releases and press comments that I would estimate the figure at about 90 per cent-of Tibetan people support the Dalai Lama not only as a religious figure but also as a political figure. Everywhere we went in Tibet that was quite clear. People were asking for photographs of the Dalai Lama, irrespective of whether they were 10-year-old monks or very elderly people.

Another member of our delegation, Kevin Garratt, who is a Tibetan linguist and expert, described Chinese policy in Tibet as ringbarking the culture. Australia has a long knowledge of the impact of ringbarking trees. It is a very apt description of the way in which the culture of Tibet is being slowly starved by present policies.

There will always be dissent and disruption in Tibet by the Tibetan people against the Chinese authorities while no accommodation is reached with the Dalai Lama and proper Tibetan autonomy. We urge in our report that the Chinese Government enter into a serious dialogue with the Dalai Lama to reach an accommodation for proper autonomy within Tibet so that the Tibetan culture, language and people can govern their own affairs at a level that the rest of the world would see as reasonable and therefore overcome the cycle of dissent and uprisings which then leads to repression in all its forms.

I said earlier in my remarks that when we went to China we did not have any great expectations that we would be able to get people released from prison or that we would be able to dramatically change Chinese law. We went there to establish hopefully the beginning of a dialogue. I believe that that was our major aim and we successfully achieved it. In a meeting that was organised very quickly at our request, we spoke with Zhu Rongji, the Vice-Premier of China, one of the three or four senior leaders of the country. An indication of how important the Chinese saw our visit was the fact that we were able to meet with Vice-Premier Zhu.

In the very open discussion we had with him, he made it clear that there is now a formal dialogue established between Australia and China. It is formal and open, which means that in the future Australia can raise with the Chinese Government, without inhibition, human rights issues. We might not always get the answer we like but at least we have established that channel for dialogue. This means that individual cases can be raised, although most of them will be raised privately. General issues can also be raised. That is a small but very significant step forward.

I also believe that Zhu Rongji's invitation to the delegation to return to China in the near future is a significant step forward. As the Minister said, although the Chinese have held the formal view for a long time that human rights are an internal matter for China, the fact that they have invited us back to discuss human rights issues means that they are accepting that human rights are on the international agenda. No matter how much an individual country may wish to ignore them, the members of the rest of the world community will raise them when they are concerned about the evidence in a particular country.

I believe that the invitation to return is an offer that should be taken up during next year. Members of the delegation are more than willing to be part of that delegation on its return. I believe that there is a good case to be said for as far as possible having the same members of the delegation return to China. What we learnt on our first visit to China about the Chinese system of government and the contacts we made have given us a well-established basis to improve the level of dialogue and raise particular issues again even more strongly.

I conclude by making two points. Firstly, it is said that, as a Western country, we should be sensitive to the cultural differences of other countries in how they see human rights, which may not be the same as in a Western democracy. I believe that we should not put too much weight on that view. Human rights are basic rights for all people. No matter whether one is a peasant in China or Ethiopia or is an oppressed person in Eastern Europe or wherever, one is entitled to enjoy the basic rights that everyone understands. Poor illiterate peasants do not want their families gaoled at will, their crops confiscated without compensation, or members of their families tortured and held without trial for long periods. These basic individual human rights are, in my view, well understood by ordinary people all over the world, irrespective of the different political cultures of different countries. I do not think that Australia should be in any way backward in raising issues of individual human rights, despite differing political cultures.

Finally, I would like to comment on why we should not let up and why dialogue with China is important. In the discussion about China's legal system, the delegation got into long dialogue about the definition of political crimes, such as counter-revolutionary activity. We tried to get from the Chinese officials what these things actually meant. I gave an example to one official. I asked whether putting up a sign outside a house saying `Down with Deng Xiaoping' was a counter-revolutionary crime? The official paused and said, `If it is an attack on Deng Xiaoping personally, it is not a counter-revolutionary crime. But if it is an attack on the State and the existence of the State, it is a counter-revolutionary crime'. I then asked who decides upon the definition. The response was confused, which indicates the real problem of human rights in a country such as China. The legal system does not define such things as counter-revolutionary activity. The definition is whatever the local official concerned with the incident defines it to be. Therefore, nobody is sure whether the activities being carried out are legal or illegal and it becomes a standard, repressive measure. If people are not sure of the definition of the law, they therefore do nothing in case they act contrary to the law.

The dialogue with the representatives of China should be about making it clear to them that over time their law has to be reformed and that the wonderful clauses in their constitution talking about equality, et cetera, have to be carried out in their administrative law and clearly defined so that people can understand them. These things should not left to the whim of an individual official because when that happens, there will be abuses of human rights and basically a lawless system will result. There are the beginnings of signs amongst Chinese officials that they understand that, if they want a modern, technologically based industrial society, they have to have the rule of law well established, and understand that there cannot be a modern society with a modern economy without understanding the need for individual human rights.

I was honoured to lead the delegation to China. Our report is by no means a definitive one on the human rights situation in China. We hope that it has begun the dialogue between both countries and become a document for debate, not only within Australia but also in the international community so that the international community with Australia can be involved in continuing the pressure on the Chinese Government to improve human rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Human Rights Delegation to China and Tibet was not an easy one. Nevertheless, it was a fascinating and, I believe, extremely worthwhile experience. I am very pleased that I went. I am grateful that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) invited me to be part of the delegation, and I hope that I was able to make a worthwhile contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the significant differences between Australian and Chinese interpretations of human rights, I was encouraged by the relative willingness of the Chinese to discuss human rights with the delegation, particularly towards the end of the trip. I was also encouraged by the seniority of the bureaucrats with whom we met. Vice-Premier Zhu Rongji indicated that the Chinese Government regards the process of dialogue begun by the delegation's visit to be both formal and open and that the delegation would be welcome to return for a further visit. I believe that this is a significant step in Sino-Australian relations and a significant step towards China's acceptance of human rights as a legitimate universal concern. As Senator Schacht has said, we never expected this delegation to change the world in one fell swoop. However, we still believe that this was a worthwhile initiative.

One of the larger sections of the delegation's report is concerned with its perceptions of Tibet. I must admit that Tibet was one of my main interests on this trip. Tibet is the saddest place to which I have ever been. We were in Lhasa for four days. We found the oppressive presence of armed security forces everywhere, including about 20 paces behind us wherever we went.

The word `Tibet' conjures up majestic and mystical images and sounds: the awesome magnificence of the Himalayas; vast plains; craggy, snow covered, cloud shrouded mountains, unimaginably high to those of us who are used to thinking of Mount Kosciusko as the highest mountain in our continent. Tibet is known by many names: the Roof of the World; the Land of Snows; Shangri-la; and the Forbidden Kingdom-all romantic and beautiful names. Tibet still has the aura to most of those who have not seen it of an inviolable and charmed country. But this pristine image is a false one.

The reality is that since the Chinese occupation of Tibet in the 1950s the destruction of this beautiful and fragile area has been immense. In our four days in Tibet, we were able to see Lhasa and some of the surrounding countryside. As Lhasa is 12,000 feet above sea level, most of us suffered to some degree from altitude sickness, which did not help our mobility. Nevertheless, we were all determined to see and do as much as possible in our short time in Tibet; in fact, we did achieve much.

The most striking features of our visit to Tibet were the massive presence of military installations and personnel; the deeply religious nature of the Tibetan people; the stark difference between the two cultures, with the consequent suffocation of the Tibetan culture; and the enormous support among the Tibetan people for the Dalai Lama. Everywhere we went we were asked surreptitiously and openly for photographs of the Dalai Lama. Among the striking features of Tibet, the most striking is the landscape, which is spectacular, remote and wild.

The forests of Tibet represent the largest forested landmass now available to China. Domestic demand for timber in China is rising steadily, growing by 44 per cent from 1982 to 1988. According to official Chinese reports, timber worth $US54 billion has been logged in Tibet since 1959. It is interesting to contrast that figure with the $US3.3 billion which we were told has been generously given to the Tibet autonomous region by the central Chinese Government during that period. This means that the value of the timber alone taken out of Tibet is equal to 16 times the value of the aid given back to the region.

Tibet is also reported to hold rich reserves of more than 40 minerals, including copper, gold, iron ore, borax, jade, magnesium, nickel, silver, tungsten, petroleum, coal and, importantly, uranium reserves which are estimated to be the largest in the world. Since the 1950s the Chinese have substantially worked many of these deposits. It is estimated that the value of borax extracted from North Tibet enabled the Chinese to repay their debt to the Russians incurred during the 1940s and 1950s.

The main forests of Tibet are in the Brahmaputra catchment area. Kingdon Ward, who visited the area in the 1920s and 1930s, described how every village was sheltered by trees such as pear, crab apple, willow, walnut and white poplar. He considered that in summer it would be one of the most delightful spots in the world. A very different scene is described by Clair Longrigg and Bradley Rowe in their article `Deforestation in Western China'. The article states:

Endless convoys of timber trucks travel from expanded towns . . . and many of the nearby hillsides have been shaved bare. Perhaps the most distressing sight is the sheer waste of wood. Only the largest trunks are removed by truck and the rest is left to rot. No effort is made to replant and soil erosion on the steep slopes soon ensures that regeneration of the forests becomes virtually impossible. Downstream, the increased silt levels pose a serious risk of floods in India and Bangladesh.

In Chengdu, we saw several trucks coming from Tibet laden with logs of varying size, the largest of which were massive. Sawn logs were also in evidence in the river to the west of Chengdu, coming from the Himalayas. The greatest devastation is reported to be in the catchment area of the Yangtze where tributaries have been stripped so bare that they are described by Longrigg and Rowe as `deserts'.

An eminent British botanist, visiting the Yangtze catchment in 1986, observed over 80 per cent loss of forest and no serious attempt at reforestation. He was told that a quarter of a million walnut trees were declared elitist during the cultural revolution and were promptly destroyed. The cultural revolution must have been one of the most senselessly destructive periods in world history. Throughout China and Tibet, we were frequently confronted by the consequences of the mass hysteria of that time. While our Chinese hosts, whose lives had been intimately affected by the cultural revolution for a very long time, did not appear to be as appalled and distressed by it as we were, they showed deep regret and sorrow over the excesses of that period.

The magnificent Ganden Monastery, built into the side of a remote mountain, which must once have been one of the most breathtaking sights in the world, is now a collection of heaps of rubble. It is being painstakingly and slowly rebuilt by peasants and the monastic community. During the cultural revolution, the vast majority of the treasures of the Tibetan monasteries and nunneries were looted by the Chinese. Statues were melted down, sold or used as landfill. Other precious artefacts also disappeared and religious texts were destroyed en masse.

We were frequently told of the marvels of modernisation in Tibet, as evidenced by the building of roads. Before 1950, there were few roads in Tibet. By 1970, a comprehensive network of roads had been established. Since then, hundreds of minor roads have been built to give access to remote areas. Large volume timber transport and, therefore, forest destruction is impossible without roads. I do not recall seeing any other vehicles on the roads outside Lhasa besides military transports.

Over a decade ago, the problem of deforestation was identified and apparently accepted by the Chinese. However, Landsat images, eyewitness reports and assessments by Chinese and Tibetan environmentalists all demonstrate that deforestation is continuing at an alarming rate, with no prospect of being arrested. The China Daily reported in March 1989 that only 26 million out of 153 million hectares replanted in the last 40 years had survived. Replanting has concentrated on `the four besides'-beside water, beside houses, beside fields and beside roads. Replanting remote areas has a very low priority.

Since the 1950s, snow leopards, blue sheep, antelope, gazelle, deer, kiang, mountain cats, musk deer and bears-all of which roamed freely in Tibet in harmony with each other and the land-have all but disappeared. In and around Lhasa, we saw some sheep and cattle, hundreds of dogs and yaks. Indeed, in my experience, yaks have an all pervasive presence in Tibet. Yak butter has a scent uniquely its own and a scent which I shall never forget. The drinking of yak butter tea is a unique experience.

The delegation's brief was, of course, to obtain information on Chinese policies affecting human rights. Chinese policies in Tibet appear to adversely affect almost every aspect of the life of Tibetans. This is summed up in paragraph 8 of the chapter on Tibet. It states:

Tibetans unconnected with the Government overwhelmingly opposed Chinese control of Tibet, sought independence and the return of the Dalai Lama, were unequivocal about lack of religious freedom and civil and political rights and talked of a lack of justice, education, employment and freedom of expression, as well as restrictions on movement. They asserted that Tibetan culture and religion were gradually being submerged by the sheer weight of Chinese influences. The Delegation was told of their fear of arrest, interrogation and detention for merely being seen to converse with foreigners. Monks often spoke of close surveillance, yet the authorities insisted that security personnel were only stationed inside the major monasteries to protect property-

that is, what property is left. Many of these fears were backed up by empirical evidence. Although outward manifestations of religious observance were in evidence at most sites the delegation visited, it appears that the foundations of Tibetan Buddhism inside Tibet are crumbling. The number of teachers able to impart the doctrine to the next generation is very small and is declining. Scholars with whom the delegation met attested to the difficulty of attaining high academic standards nowadays. Very few religious personnel are qualified at the highest level. Study is made difficult because fewer monks and nuns means those who are left have heavier workloads and teachers are few and far between. Education can be freely obtained in the Tibetan language at primary school level but becomes more difficult to obtain at secondary school level. Tertiary education is available only in Chinese, except for Tibetan Studies.

Most of China's nuclear testing is reported to have taken place at Lop Nor, on the northern border of Tibet. However, the delegation received no answer to questions about nuclear testing. We did not meet any officials who had any information on nuclear or chemical weapons or on the disposition or size of the People's Liberation Army in Tibet. According to the US Tibet Committee, however, one quarter of the People's Liberation Army nuclear force is located in Tibet.

It is interesting to note that, although to my untrained eye about half the population of Lhasa appeared to be Han Chinese-a great many of them in uniform-the people I spoke to were not keen to stay in Tibet for any more time than was strictly necessary. They were all looking forward to returning home at the end of their contracts.

Before 1950, Tibet was inhabited by Tibetan tribes and a few Mongol settlers from the time of Kublai Khan. The only Chinese were a few traders and administrators in market towns along the main caravan routes. At least in Lhasa that situation has changed dramatically.

I would like to say a few words about the members of the delegation. It was a very hard-working delegation. I believe that, in one radio interview, Senator Schacht described the trip as `gruelling'. I would agree with that. We extended our meetings as long as we possibly could and, in general, we would get back to the hotel after one meeting and would have to be back in the lobby in 10 minutes to get going for the next meeting. If we were lucky, we had up to half an hour in which to get ready for dinner.

Senator Schacht led the delegation with some style. He generally remained quite calm, even after considerable provocation, and always knew exactly where the fine line was between forceful advocacy of human rights and pushing the Chinese too far. I can recall one incident when he told our translator-and I hope I am not misquoting him- `translate this very carefully-that is a ridiculous excuse and an insult to our intelligence'. I must admit that I waited with some trepidation to see whether we would ever get out of the Beijing No. 1 prison, but we did. Senator Schacht demonstrated yet again that he had not gone far enough over the line for us to have caused trouble, although I must say that I believe that they were pleased to see the back of us when we left that establishment. Mr Connolly added panache to the delegation, although it was a bit of a shame that he spent his birthday on the sick list in Tibet. In spite of that, he demonstrated remarkable determination by attending meetings.

Professor Fitzgerald is obviously still well known and well respected throughout China. His knowledge of Chinese history and affairs and his ability to speak fluent Mandarin were invaluable. Professor Tay is an amazing woman. Her knowledge of the Chinese legal system is extensive and very detailed, and her language skills were very useful. She was also the most disgustingly healthy and energetic person on the delegation. Mr Sidoti had a special interest in prison and detention centre conditions and race discrimination. He also had some very interesting ideas concerning a visit to Tiananmen Square but, unfortunately, we were unable to find the time for that.

Mr Sheppard, the delegation secretary, has an extensive knowledge of Australia's actions and policies in the field of human rights. Dr Rigby is said by the Chinese themselves to speak better Mandarin than many Chinese. Mr Garratt's expertise in the Tibetan language and culture were absolutely invaluable. He is also the only westerner I have ever met who actually likes yak butter tea. He drank it voluntarily at breakfast.

A lot of hard work was put in by all members during the preparation, during the trip and afterwards in writing up the report. Despite the disparate nature of the substantial contributions to the first draft from all members, I believe that the finished report is a cohesive and competent reflection of the delegation's findings and I am very pleased to be associated with it.

I must emphasise that I truly believe that the only way in which the Chinese Government will ever come to any satisfactory arrangement with the Tibetan people is by recognising their fundamental human rights as set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the international human rights covenants, and by negotiating without preconditions with the Dali Lama. Most honourable senators will know that article 1 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights calls for the self-determination of peoples. The Tibetans are a distinct people with a distinct history, appearance and culture. I believe that they are entitled to self-determination.

On our last day in China, I was asked by one of our escorts whether, now that I had been to Tibet and seen the conditions there for myself, I was still a splittist-someone who wants Tibet to be split from China. All I can say is that, after having visited Tibet, I am now more of a splittist than I was when I first moved in the Australian Parliament a motion on Tibet. If the Tibetan people want to govern themselves, they should be able to do so.

Europe is changing. Africa and Asia are changing. China cannot maintain the democratic dictatorship of the proletariat forever. The political unrest throughout Tibet and China itself cannot be contained much longer. While China has made significant advances since the dark days of the cultural revolution, it cannot be denied that the human rights situation in Tibet in particular leaves much to be desired. I believe that the delegation made this point strongly throughout China and Tibet. I hope that we have encouraged the Chinese Government to come closer to accepting the universality of human rights. If we have, the trip has been worth while.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth discussion paper prepared by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs relating to the Committee's cost of legal services and litigation inquiry and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I present a discussion paper entitled Methods of Dispute Resolution prepared by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs as part of its inquiry into the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia. This is the fourth discussion paper prepared by the Committee as part of this inquiry. It is directed towards the examination of paragraph (d) of its terms of reference, which requires the Committee to inquire into and report on whether there are any practicable alternatives to the present legal system.

The Committee is aware that the methods of dispute resolution available outside the formal litigation process have been the subject of some considerable interest in recent times. It is also aware that they have been the topic of a considerable number of investigations and reports. However, evidence that the Committee has obtained so far leads it to the view that it is possible that alternative dispute resolution techniques, if properly used, would result in savings in the system. Therefore, the Committee is going to consider them in some detail as part of its `cost of justice' inquiry. The discussion paper is designed to further the current debate concerning methods of dispute resolution and to highlight issues on which the Committee would welcome further evidence. I emphasise that it does not represent the Committee's final views concerning this aspect of its inquiries.

I would like now make some comments about the people who prepared the discussion paper. Stephen Marshall, who unfortunately has left us, did splendid work on the paper together with Fiona Matthews, who has been an adornment to the Committee since she joined it. James Warmenhoven, the Acting Secretary, has also done a lot of good work. The departing Secretary, Bronwyn McNaughton, who has gone to Harvard to become an ivy leaguer, also deserves mention.

The development of an alternative dispute resolution is worth pursuing. However, the question always arises as to what jurisdiction the superior courts of the land should have over that. I am very conscious of the concern that the Supreme Court judges of Victoria had about that. They dealt with it in their 1988 annual report. I notice that reference is made in the discussion paper to the Supreme Court of Australia. Of course, it should be the Supreme Court of Victoria, and that will be corrected when the final report is presented.

The other matter that I am very conscious of is the very recent decision in the Polyukhovich war crimes case, in which the High Court of Australia also turned to the question of how the judiciary should have control of the decision-making process in so far as that decision making relates to matters judicial. The Committee and I will turn our minds to the extent to which the legislature or the Executive-an arm of government outside the judiciary-can discuss and properly look at matters such as those that are contained in this paper, bearing in mind what the High Court has said about matters to do with the administration of justice, including the question of costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to protect threatened species in Australia and overseas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Bill and seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take the Bill further at this stage. I am tabling the Bill as an exposure draft for the consideration of honourable senators and others and to stimulate discussion on this important subject. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement explaining the purpose of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
I have great pleasure in presenting to the Senate a Private Members Bill which seeks to protect the biodiversity of this country.

According to the United Nations Environment Program (1991), ``estimates of the number of living species on Earth vary from 5 million to 30 million, of which only 1.4 million have been identified and classified . . . '' They state that ``though there is no precise estimate of the number of species that have been lost, . . . experts believe that 25 percent of the Earth's total biological diversity is at risk of extinction during the next 20 to 30 years . . . ''
Australia, like nearly every continent on earth, is suffering a major crisis in the loss of biological diversity.

The Threatened Species Bill 1991, is designed to establish a comprehensive and co-ordinated response to the alarming loss of species that is common in this and most other countries throughout the world.
There are four reasons why we, as Australians and global citizens should preserve our biodiversity:

* Natural ecosystems, comprise a complex web of species, populations and ecological communities, providing indispensable services. Ecosystems are the life support systems of our planet. If they fail, not only will we jeopardise our current standard of living but potentially the entire wellbeing of humankind.

* Protecting biodiversity confers significant potential economic benefits. Plants, animals and micro-organisms provide all our food, and many of our drugs and medicines, and other valuable resources such as fuel, building materials, clothing, paper and leather. Novel chemicals and unexpected genetic information is being discovered continuously. Once lost a species containing this information is denied to all later generations. Options for our dependants are foreclosed. For example, some Australian marsupials contain genetic information which allows them to closely control their fertility. This information may be vital to human survival.

* The third reason for conserving species and habitats is one of cultural and aesthetic reasons. Species and habitats should be preserved because their beauty and intrinsic interest are of great emotional value to our community.
* The fourth reason is based on an ethic of concern and compassion for other creatures which share this planet with us. Other species have a right to exist.
Traditional conservation methods have not dealt with the problem of species and habitat loss adequately.

``Traditional conservation activities are too disparate, fragmented, and limited to bring about fundamental changes necessary to bring the loss of diversity to a halt. The best way to slow the loss of biodiversity is through diverse, coordinated, and participatory programs that attack the problem at its roots, builds support among wide-ranging institutions and individuals, draws on the best modern science, and establishes biodiversity conservation in its rightful place as a basic prerequisite of development policy.'' IUCN, 1990

These principles are embedded in the Threatened Species Bill presented to the Senate today. If accepted by this parliament, the Bill will provide a substantial basis for the movement of our society towards ecologically sustainable development.

``The world's renewable resources, such as forests, fisheries, wildlife, and crops, are of immense use to people, while the genetic diversity of these resources allows continued adaptation to the world's changing conditions. What's more, the highly diverse natural ecosystems that support this wealth of species also maintain hydrological cycles, regulate climate, build soils, absorb and break down pollutants, and provide sites for spiritual enrichment, tourism and research. To waste Earth's riches, is to rob the world's rural poor of sustainable livelihoods, and deprive future generations of the resources they will need to survive and prosper.'' IUCN, 1990
This Threatened Species Bill will begin to address the fundamental causes of the loss of our wildlife and as a consequence the stability of our ecosystems.
GLOBAL SPECIES EXTINCTION
The IUCN (1990) note that:

``The world is being impoverished by the loss and degradation of its most fundamental living resources-its genes, species, habitats, and ecosystems . . . This loss of the planet's living richness is both wrong and dangerous. Wrong, because we should accept that all species have a right to exist, as the U.N. General Assembly stated when it adopted the World Charter for Nature in 1982. Dangerous, because the world's environmental systems are humanity's life-support mechanisms, and we do not know which components are key to maintaining their essential functions.''

Professor Michael Archer, from the University of New South Wales describes humanity's destruction of its life support systems most graphically. He argues that ``we have to book ourselves into the same league as the comet that may have struck the earth and obliterated half of the vertebrates from the world 65 million years ago. We are that sort of catastrophe. We are an extincting force, the like of which the world has never seen before''. (Earthworm, May 1991)

A British ecologist puts it just as graphically when he calls man's destruction of nature as the ``greatest setback to life's abundance and diversity since the first flickering's of life almost 4 billion years ago.'' (Time Magazine Jan, 1989)

It is incredibly arrogant for Homo sapiens, in 1991, to think that it knows enough about the operation of the natural world that, in any sense, it will work better or even as well with more and more species being removed through humanity's uncaring exploitation.
AUSTRALIA'S RECORD SINCE EUROPEAN SETTLEMENT

The problem of species extinction is not restricted to overseas countries. Indeed, European Australia has one of the worst records of species extinction of any country and our extinction rates are still unacceptably high-even today.
In the past 200 years, since the settlement of this continent by Europeans, Australia is known to have lost 30 large and visible animals and 100 plants.

Professor Harry Recher from the University of New England notes that ``Recognition of the impact of European settlement on the Australian landscape and its flora and fauna has been slow to emerge. Most Australians view the continent as vast, unspoiled and underpopulated. Yet in historical times, no other continent has experienced the massive changes in the distribution and abundance of such a large proportion of its vertebrate fauna as has Australia. In 200 years Europeans have recast the evolutionary biogeography of the continent.''
And this appalling record is continuing. Australia has an estimated 111 animals and nearly 1000 plants that are currently threatened with extinction. (Endangered Species Program)

But unlike other nations, the great tragedy is that most Australians don't even know about the wildlife we are destroying. Australians know more about the plight of the African elephant or the Bengal tiger than they do about the Thylacine, the Bilby or the Quoll. That indeed is a great tragedy that we must urgently redress if we are to gain community support in preserving our biodiversity.

It is an outrage, that a nation whose high standard of living is dependant almost entirely on the natural environmental assets of this continent, can have such little regard for its continued health, and show such indifference to the plight of many unique native species that share this continent with us.
THE CAUSES OF EXTINCTION
To satisfactorily address the real causes of extinction, it is necessary to turn to principles of population ecology and to the historical record.
Three processes affect the extinction of species (Clark, 1990). They are described in figure 1.

Extinction is a complex process which occurs over many years. It is not simply the death of the last individual of a species. The first stage involves major systematic factors such as habitat loss or change. Populations become fragmented.

Secondly, random factors, such a drought, fire and floods are unpredictable in occurrence and consequence. The smaller the population size, the more susceptible it is to extinction from chance events (Shaffer, 1981).
The third process wipes out the remaining isolated individuals or small groups. By now extinction os inevitable without expensive and very deliberate human intervention.
Extinction occurs at the level of populations and not at the level of species (Gilpin &Soule, 1986). Because of this, conservation strategies must focus on managing for population viability.
