The following examples work at one or several of these levels in Australia:
* Habitat destruction, from expanding human populations and activities, because most species cannot exist outside natural or semi-natural ecosystems;
* Habitat change and degradation, such as changed fire regimes, weed invasion, erosion and grazing by introduced herbivores;
* Introduced animals, such as the fox and cat which are now abundant and are implicated in the disappearance of remnant populations of mammals and ground-dwelling birds;
* Introduced plants, which have in some instances taken over complete ecosystems;
* Introduced diseases, such as a root fungus in south-western Australia where in some places 90% of the plant biomass can be lost;
* Direct exploitation, by hunting of animals such as the Thylacine, Southern Right Whales and Fur Seals;

* Climatic change, which is increasingly likely to be a cause of extinction in the future due to changes caused by the greenhouse effect and the difficulty for remnant natural ecosystems to adapt; and
* an interaction of one or more of the above causes.

A substantial proportion of the current extinctions and threats of extinction have come from a combination of habitat alteration, introduction of herbivores, such as sheep, cattle and the rabbit, and the introduction of predators such as the fox and cat.

``With this theory of extinction as a background, it seems obvious that in developing management strategies for species conservation, we need to manage populations and their habitats with the goal of maintaining large, viable populations of all wildlife species. This notion is at the heart of preventative conservation programs. If we do not carry out these programs, we will be forced into crisis intervention in case after case-an expensive and time consuming proposition.'' (Clark, 1990)
This principle underlies this Threatened Species Bill.
HISTORY OF SPECIES EXTINCTION IN AUSTRALIA

Recher and Lim (1990) note that ``The impact of European settlement (on terrestrial fauna) has been greatest on mammals and birds. In the 200 years since the colony was established in 1788 at Port Jackson, 17 species of terrestrial mammals, three taxa of birds and the Adelaide blue-tongue lizard are known to have become extinct.
``Eight species of mammals formerly occurring on the mainland survive only on isolated, small offshore islands.''
Many people think that the great extinctions of our wildlife and their habitats occurred in the very early days of European settlement and that damage has all but stopped.
This view could not be farther from the truth. The rates of extinction on this continent are as rapid now as they were at any time in the past.

Recher and Lim (1990) state that: ``In describing the decline and extinction of the Australian terrestrial vertebrate fauna, we are not describing changes over 200 years of settlement. Instead, most events occurred within 20 or 30 years of an area being settled. For most of the continent the changes described occurred within this century. The impact of Europeans on the Australian environment is not measured in centuries, but in decades. This pattern is now being repeated in the south-west and north-west of the continent as settlement of these regions intensifies.''
THE THREATENING PROCESS
Many of the mammal extinctions and threats can be linked to this combination of factors and frequently they occur over a relatively short period of time.

Recher and Lim (1990), predict that ``there will be further significant declines in the distribution and abundance of birds throughout the same regions where the native mammal fauna has already disappeared. These will follow the same pattern as the mammals with the rapid extinction of species or a reduction in abundance to small, tenuous relict populations persisting where conditions remain marginally favourable. Although we talk of species, the patterns described are of entire ecosystems disappearing. The scale of change is not of individuals or populations, but of functional units of interacting organisms. Once destroyed, it is no more likely that an ecosystem can be restored to its original state any more than an extinct species can be resurrected from its bones recovered from a museum draw.''
If Australia is to save its fauna and flora, emphasis needs to shift from, species preservation to the management of ecosystems.
The Threatened Species Bill recognises that preserving biodiversity means retaining viable populations in natural ecosystems.
A 5 STEP PLAN TO SAVE OUR
BIODIVERSITY

The Australian Democrats suggest a 5 point plan that we believe the government can and should adopt, to reverse the threatening processes that affect the species in our unique natural and rural environments. The Threatened Species Bill is one important part of this plan.
Step 1: Funding to conserve threatened species and habitats

The Federal Government proudly boasts an Endangered Species Program which provides funding of $5 million this year. This represents 0.005% of the Federal budget. The Federal Government's current funding level represents about 31 cents a year for each Australian to save its irreplaceable heritage.
This Government spent more on landscaping the grounds around this Parliament House, than they have spent on saving species in Australia in the past three years.

Under the current financial and structural arrangements, the Endangered Species Program is reactive in its outlook and will do little to overcome the enormous problem we are facing with the loss of species and habitats.

Michael Kennedy, from the World Wide Fund for Nature has described the current level of funding as ``laughable''. He has stated that this level of funding is perhaps a thousandth of what we need for the coming decades.
``It will not serve to stop the growing list of species under threat, it will simply serve to watch the list grow longer: it's just not enough.'' (Earthworm 22/5/91)

Unless we as Australians make a commitment now to start to fix the fundamental problems with the management of our natural environment we are never going to solve the problem, and extinctions will continue.

This lack of funding is compounded by the lack of certainty and continuity of funding. This lack of continuity leads to programs being devised which do not take a long term perspective and instead rely on achieving quantifiable results in the short term.

As a nation, we were able to plan a 25 year Snowy Mountains Scheme to help improve our economic wellbeing, but it appears a far simpler task of providing funding certainty to repair our natural environment cannot be done.
That of course is a nonsense-the problem in not the inability to provide certainty, it is the lack of political will to do so.

Australia must prepare, in consultation with the community, conservation, industry, farm, fishing and forestry groups, a 200 year Australian conservation plan, which contains action plans, and funding targets for a least the first 10 years of this plan.

If it is good enough for the government to build a Parliament House to last 200 years, it is good enough for that Parliament to prepare a plan to ensure our environmental heritage is protected for that same amount of time.

The 200 year plan must integrate the management of all extinction threatening processes: the loss of habitat, protecting endangered species, populations and ecological communities, and controlling the numbers, type and range of many feral animals.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Conservation Strategy should be jointly managed by appropriate government departments and community groups to ensure that the most efficient funding programs are put in place and that the community feels part of the process of saving our environment. Bureaucracy alone is unlikely to achieve these goals effectively.

By 1994-95 funding for this program should reach $100 million per annum, with $40 million being for habitat protection (replacing the Save the Bush Program), $30 million for ensuring the survival of threatened species, and $30 million for the control of feral animals.
Step 2: An enhanced National Landcare Program

The existing Landcare program is an excellent initiative of the government, in that is encourages local communities to become involved directly in the conservation of their local environment. For this it should be complimented. However, we consider that funding of the program is not adequate, because the task is enormous and because landcare is a responsibility of all Australians and all Australians should share the financial cost of repair.

CSIRO claims that ``since European settlement some 52 per cent of Australia's agricultural and pastoral lands have been degraded and are now in need of reclamation. There is no reliable estimate of the cost of land degradation to Australia, nor of the status of our soils. Many believe that the value of the lost production is in excess of $600 million per year.''

This problem needs to be overcome rapidly if we are protect our agricultural economy and the natural environment on which it depends. The Australian Democrats would suggest therefore that the current program be expanded and restructured under the title of the ``National Landcare Program''.

Administration of the program should be by a National Landcare Council. This Council should be responsible to the Minister for Primary Industry, and comprise representatives from the Dept. Primary Industries and Energy, Dept. Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation, the National Farmers Federation, The Australian Conservation Foundation and Greening Australia.
The National Landcare Council should include the existing National Soil Conservation Program, the One Billion Trees scheme, the National Water Research Program.

Funding levels should commence at $90 million in 1991-92 and increase to $170 million in 1993-94. Internal funding arrangement's should shift from an initial emphasis on research and extension to ensure the correct action is taken.

As the Landcare groups become more organised, and as the research and information on species types and planting techniques improves, a greater proportion of the increased funding should go to these groups.
Step 3: Biological and resource information research
It is critical to the management of our natural environment that we know what it consists of and how species interact with each other.
The Australian Biological Resources Survey (ABRS) which was established in 1973 is therefore, one of the most significant activities being undertaken in Australia at the present time.
The ABRSs role is to identify the kinds of plants and animals that are in Australia and where these plants and animals are found.

The work of the ABRS is fundamental to any discussion on ecologically sustainable development. Without the basic information about the environment which we inhabit, it is impossible to plan an ecologically sustainable future.

However the level of funding given to the ABRS is so inadequate that it will not complete its work until the year 3000! This is clearly ridiculous and the government should set a priority to have the data base of all known flora and fauna completed in time for the bicentenary of Federation in 2001.
ABRS must be expanded and incorporate a program which I have called the Australian Biological and Environmental Survey. This program should:

* survey the type and location of all major Australian flora and fauna. This would allow the ABRS and their Environmental Resources Information Network (ERIN) to upgrade their existing programs and undertake a comprehensive national biological and environmental resources survey;

* include a National Land Capability Assessment (NLCA) program of the Australian continent, Australian ocean fisheries and all Territories. The NLCA should survey all natural and rural lands in Australia; and

* establish an Environmental Resource Library (ERL) that provides access to data and modelling capabilities to interested nongovernment organisations on the same principle as that of a public library.

This program should receive funding of $24 million per annum, with $5 million towards the existing ABRS, $3 million for the NLCA, $15 million for ERIN and $1 million for the ERL. Such funding should be guaranteed for the next 10 years.
Step 4: Management of natural resources based on sustained yield harvesting

The Government should get fair dinkum about the long term management of our natural resources through proper research, monitoring and setting sustainable catch/harvest limits on our renewable resources, rather than trying to continue to deplete our environmental capital to hold up a poorly managed economy.

History has shown this to be a very difficult concept for our community to deal with, and considerable resources need to be put into achieving these principles. The history of our forest industries and fisheries are testament to poor management of renewable resources in the past.

The Government should abandon its proposed resource security legislation. The ACF is quite correct when it states that ``resource security legislation is subsidising industry to destroy native forests''.
This was most clearly spelt out in The Australian on the 5th July where it noted that:
``In a rundown of the various State (Forestry) Commission performances . . . :
* Tasmania had not made a profit since 1935 and by 1989 has a notional shortfall of $520 million;
* Queensland had not made a profit since 1947, and its cumulative loss, in current terms, was more than $1.5 billion;
* The cumulative loss in Western Australia since the mid 1960s was $440 million;
* Victoria had cumulative shortfalls of about $1 billion by 1984, although much of this could be due to substantial investments in plantations;
* NSW had reported surpluses for two years, but had carried forward investment of more than $1 billion since 1981; and
* South Australia had a surplus since 1983.''

Step 4 in the Democrats plan is therefore administratively quite simple-the Government should immediately withdraw its intention to establish Resource Security legislation, put a real price on the value of our publicly owned renewable resources, such as the timber in our native forests and allow plantation forestry to become economically viable, instead of subsidising an inefficient and environmentally destructive industry.
Step 5: Legislation to protect endangered species

Step 5 is the legislative component of the programs I have just suggested. This Threatened Species Bill is designed to implement this essential element in a comprehensive national conservation program.

In a letter to the Minister in May this year, the peak conservation groups (WWF, ACF, TWS and Greenpeace) stated that ``One of the most important tools in carrying out this long term recovery task is the development of Commonwealth Threatened Species Legislation.''
Endangered species legislation has been in existence in the United States since 1983, and it is urgent that Australia introduce such legislation.
PROPOSED THREATENED SPECIES BILL

This Bill establishes a community based Commonwealth Threatened Species Advisory Committee (which includes conservationists, farmer groups, educators and scientists), and a Scientific Advisory Panel which provides scientific advice to the Committee and the Minister.
Administration of the Bill is to be by a Threatened Species Unit, which is given guidance in the administration of programs by the Advisory Committee and the Scientific Panel.

The Bill establishes endangered species lists which identify threatened species, populations and ecological communities which the Commonwealth is obliged to protect, and requires the implementation of Threatened Species Recovery Plans.
The Bill also gives power to the Minister to issue Conservation Orders to restrain acts that are likely to be detrimental to threatened species, populations or ecological communities.
It provides for compensation to landholders who may be financially affected by aspects of this legislation or who wish to enter into voluntary Habitat Management Agreements with the Minister.
Objects

The objectives of the Threatened Species Bill are to redress the fundamental problems facing Australia in the continuing loss of its biodiversity. The Bill identifies six objectives which address this problem. They are to:
(a) ensure that threatened species, populations and ecological communities can survive and flourish;
(b) ensure that threatened species, populations and ecological communities retain their genetic diversity and potential for evolutionary development in their natural habitat;
(c) prevent further species, populations and ecological communities from becoming endangered;
(d) encourage the States by way of resources and financial incentives, to introduce complimentary threatened species legislation;
(e) provide programs-
(i) of community education in the conservation of flora and fauna; and
(ii) to encourage co-operative management of flora and fauna between government authorities, corporations, landholders, community groups and individuals; and
(f) assist other nations and negotiate international treaties to protect the biological heritage of humankind.
Powers to Protect Biodiversity

The Bill requires the Commonwealth to properly exercise its powers to protect threatened species, populations and ecological communities by imposing controls on the activities of government agencies, within Commonwealth Territories and, by foreign corporations and trading corporations.
Community Participation

The success of conservation of biodiversity lies in extensive processes of community co-operation and involvement in specific programs that overcome the processes that threaten species with extinction.

These participatory procedures are vital if the community at large is to feel that protection of biodiversity is a responsibility of all of us, and not just government and scientists who have traditionally administered conservation programs. They are essential if governments are to have the widespread community support for these protection programs.
The task is far too great to rely on a few people-it must involve the whole community through education and local action and co-operation.
A community based, Commonwealth Threatened Species Advisory Committee is therefore established, which is to have a major influence in the management of endangered species programs.

This Advisory Committee comprises three government appointed officers and six representatives nominated by community groups such as the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Conservation Foundation, Greening Australia, the World Wide Fund for Nature (Australia), and the Australian Association for Environmental Education.

This Committee is given wide responsibility for overseeing programs and for providing guidance and assistance to the Minister on matters relating to conservation. These responsibilities include giving guidance on the preparation and of a Commonwealth Threatened Species Conservation Strategy, the preparation of Species Recovery Plans, and on the preparation of Threatening Process Action Plans.

In addition to the establishment of this and other community committees, the Bill gives any person or organisation the authority to nominate a species, population or ecological community as threatened, and also allows any member of the community to take action through the courts to ensure that a threatened species are given full protection under the Act.
Financial Assistance and Advice

The Bill provides for Commonwealth financial support to the States. It also provides for financial support and expertise to be given to landholders, conservation organisations, local government bodies and Landcare groups that wish to assist in the conservation of Australia's biodiversity.
This financial support includes grants to States to facilitate development of their own threatened species legislation and to assist in the control of threatening processes.
Financial support is also made available for community involvement in the development of a national education program.
International Obligations to Protect Biodiversity

Because Australia has an important role to play in the international efforts to protect global biodiversity, the Bill also deals with Australia's international obligations and highlights Australia's responsibility towards foreign assistance programs.

The Bill establishments a Foreign Assistance Program to support less developed countries, especially those in our Pacific region, and an Advisory Committee to assist Australian representatives on international bodies such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
CONSULTATION WITH THE COMMUNITY

It is my intention to let this Bill lie on the table for a sufficient length of time to allow its full consideration by landholders, conservation groups, Landcare groups, government agencies and any other person interested in the future of our unique environment.
I also ask that Government and Opposition Senators also take advantage of this period to give the Bill serious consideration. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Crichton-Browne) agreed to:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 to make it clear that a statutory provision does not take away the privilege of freedom of speech in Parliament unless that provision expressly provides for that effect.

Until August last year it had not occurred to me, nor to any other person having any knowledge of the law relating to Parliament, that it would be necessary to have a bill to state an obvious principle.

At that time, however, an opinion of the Solicitor-General was provided to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. This opinion suggested that, in some circumstances, the secrecy provisions of section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act, although those provisions do not refer to the powers of the Committee established under the Act, could prevent the provision of evidence to that Committee.

There are many other such secrecy provisions in other acts of Parliament. Generally speaking, they provide that a person who discloses information obtained under an act without authorisation is guilty of an offence.
It had always been believed by those acquainted with the law of parliamentary privilege that these provisions could have no application to inquiries by parliamentary committees, because:

* the giving of evidence before a committee is a proceeding in Parliament, and a person may not be sued or prosecuted for anything said or done in the course of proceedings in Parliament (this was made clear by the declaratory provisions of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987)

* it is a fundamental principle, confirmed as recently as 1985 by a joint opinion of the then Attorney-General and the then Solicitor-General, that parliamentary privilege is not affected by a statutory provision unless the provision explicitly states that the law relating to parliamentary privilege is amended by the provision (if this were not so, there are innumerable statutory provisions which could be interpreted as taking away parliamentary privilege).

The Solicitor-General's opinion raised the suggestion that all of the very many statutory secrecy provisions (there are estimated to be over three hundred of them) would prevent the provision of evidence to parliamentary inquiries in relation to any matter covered by those provisions.

Such a conclusion would virtually bring the inquiry activities of the two Houses and their committees to an end, because there would be virtually no subject which could be inquired into without encountering a statutory secrecy provision.

This possibility was raised even more starkly by an opinion of the Attorney-General's Department dated 15 April 1991 and tabled in the Senate on 30 May 1991. This opinion claimed that a statutory secrecy provision, which has absolutely no reference to parliamentary inquiries in it or in the act in which it appears, would prevent the provision of information to a parliamentary committee.

On 8 November 1990 I had introduced into the Senate a bill, the National Crime Authority (Powers of Parliamentary Joint Committee) Amendment Bill 1990, to make it clear that the secrecy provisions of the National Crime Authority Act do not have any application to inquiries by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

The appearance of the Attorney-General's Department opinion, however, indicated that it was necessary to take action to deal with the effects of secrecy provisions generally. I therefore set about preparing this bill.

On 30 May 1991 another Attorney-General's Department opinion, dated 14 May 1990, was tabled in the Senate. This opinion took a completely contrary view to that of the opinion of 15 April 1991, and indicated that general statutory secrecy provisions do not prevent the giving of evidence to a parliamentary committee.
It thus appeared that the Attorney-General's Department had given contradictory advice on the matter.

In response to a question which I asked on 16 August 1991, the Minister representing the Attorney-General tabled an opinion of the Solicitor-General dated 12 August 1991. This opinion indicates that a general statutory secrecy provision does not have any application to the giving of evidence to a parliamentary committee.
This opinion, however, still gives cause for concern.

First, the Solicitor-General considers that a statutory provision may alter the law of parliamentary privilege not only by express words but also by ``necessary implication''. This raises the possibility that a secrecy provision may be interpreted as taking away parliamentary privilege if a ``necessary implication'' can be read into it. Thus it would still be a matter of interpretation as to whether a particular secrecy provision has any effect on parliamentary inquiries.

Secondly, the Solicitor-General is still of the view that the secrecy provisions of the National Crime Authority Act may have some application to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority. This is because a ` `necessary implication'' could be read into that Act.
Thirdly, the opinion implies that that secrecy provision may bind not only the Joint Committee but the Houses of the Parliament themselves.

Fourthly, the opinion suggests that the law should be ``clarified'' in relation to the presentation to parliamentary committees of information which is the subject of secrecy provisions. This raises the possibility of legislation to impose new restrictions on parliamentary inquiries.
For these reasons, I have decided to proceed with this bill.

The bill would declare, and put beyond doubt, that a statutory provision affects parliamentary privilege only if it contains express words indicating such an effect. This declaratory provision would put to rest the suggestion that a general statutory provision can be invoked to stop a parliamentary inquiry.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

upon which Senator Alston had moved by way of amendment:

(a) condemns the Government for failing to extend the proposed reforms to Australia's current unacceptably large invalid pensioner population, with the inevitable result that there will be two classes of pensioners, poor targeting and a reduced capacity to assist the most disabled.

(b) expresses its concerns at the Government's totally inadequate consultation with medical practitioners, health professionals, welfare groups and representatives of people with disabilities and their carers, resulting in serious uncertainties about the reliability and validity of the proposed Impairment Tables as well as over 100 proposed amendments since the bill was guillotined through the House of Representatives.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was interrupted by the adjournment of the Senate, I was in the middle of a speech on this Bill and was expressing my concern about the availability of assistance for people currently on invalid pensions. I was discussing the early intervention theory which the Government is putting forward as important, with which I do not agree, for getting people early when they go on disability pension and encouraging them through training and rehabilitation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has finally admitted that the eligibility criteria for the invalid pension have been too lax for many years, hence, the reduction in the effect of socioeconomic factors in 1987 and a further tightening by this legislation. Also, there were very large numbers of long term sickness beneficiaries originally with supposedly temporary ailments who had transferred to the invalid pension. During the last five years, over 100,000 people have transferred from sickness benefits to the invalid pension, with over 25,000 people transferring during the last financial year alone. If these people remain on the invalid pension, as a very high percentage of them will, they will cost the Australian taxpayer close to $1 billion a year.

I am sceptical about the applicability of early intervention theories to many people with disabilities. Often it is more difficult to cope with a disability in the period immediately following its onset. Over time, with the help of the community and family networks, it is not uncommon for there to be a marked reduction in the debilitating effect of a disability. In fact, many of the worthwhile reforms that the Government is implementing in accordance with the Disability Services Act are based on this very premise. However, the Government's income support policy for people with disabilities is based on a very different assumption; namely, that it is not worth while to assist people who were receiving invalid pensions before 1990 to access mainstream employment.

The facts are that 131,000 people or 42 per cent of current invalid pensioners are under 50 years of age. Sixty-two per cent of women receiving the invalid pension are under 50. Many of these people have significant work force potential. Not only do they possess a variety of work-related skills, but also the courage, determination and perseverance that they have exhibited in overcoming their disabilities would be a most valuable asset to any employer. What they need and what they desire is not one endless government handout, but access to training and job search assistance which will help them harness and enhance their skills so that they can achieve financial independence.

The hesitancy of the Department of Social Security in promoting these reforms does not mean that it believes that anyone who was on an invalid pension before the 1990 Budget cannot and should not be assisted. The main reason why DSS is not telling current pensioners about these reforms is that the Government has only provided sufficient rehabilitation and training places to cater for a minority of new claimants. An analysis of the allocated Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and DEET training places reveals that it would be difficult to cater for the estimated 12,000 active extreme disability service pensioners and 8,000 sickness allowees who will require rehabilitation and training annually, let alone any volunteers from the current pensioner population.

Currently, 3,000 invalid pensioners and about 3,200 sickness beneficiaries access CRS places, while DEET training programs are off-limits to these people. The Government has allocated a further 4,500 CRS places and 4,250 DEET training places to cater for these reforms. There will be an increase of 4,000 in the number of supported and competitive employment places under the Disability Services Act. There is also a commitment to provide 8,000 CRS places for sickness allowees, although how this figure impacts on the 4,500 overall allocation has not been spelt out.

The best possible scenario is a parity between places and claimants. However, a number of other factors need to be taken into account. A significant proportion of claimants will need to access more than one program of assistance before they are ready for employment. The assistance required by many people will be longer than one year in duration. Some of the 4,000 places allocated under the Disability Services Act will be taken by people who are not in the 20,000 strong active stream. All these additional training and rehabilitation resources will only be phased in over the next three years. The combination of these factors raises doubt as to whether there are sufficient resources to cater for the designated active claimants, let alone an influx of further volunteers, particularly during the interim period.

It is also important to look at the staff resources that have been allocated to implement these reforms. Initially, their administration will be coordinated by 75 disability support officers working in DSS. Their numbers will swell to 120 in 1993-94. Initially 46, but ultimately 72, DEET disability job seeker advisers will assess the training and Job Search needs of up to 24,000 clients. By 1993-94 there will also be an additional 168 CRS staff providing rehabilitation related assistance. There is little doubt that the workloads of these officers are based on an assumption that there will not be an influx of volunteers from the current pensioner population. Given the size of the staff allocation, it is also obvious that they would not be able to cope with such an influx.

A responsible government cannot simply say that the past is the past and leave over 316,000 existing invalid pensioners stranded in the too hard basket. From the start, the Government must promote these reforms within its current pensioner population. All pensioners should be informed that assistance is available and told how they can access it. Instead of using unconvincing, early intervention theory excuses, the DSS should direct some of its vast financial and staffing resources to undertaking a comprehensive study of the work force potential of its current invalid pensioner population. Upon completion of this study, work force potential indicators should be designed and used to implement a highly targeted, voluntary program of incentive based, work force related assistance measures.

In conclusion, I commend the Minister for the direction of these reforms, but in view of their restricted application one must ask whether this Government has the courage to move away from the outdated, discriminatory and wasteful concept of permanent, no questions asked welfare for people with disabilities. I support the amendment moved by Senator Alston, which states:

(a) condemns the Government for failing to extend the proposed reforms to Australia's current unacceptably large invalid pensioner population, with the inevitable result that there will be two classes of pensioners, poor targeting and a reduced capacity to assist the most disabled.

(b) expresses its concerns at the Government's totally inadequate consultation with medical practitioners, health professionals, welfare groups and representatives of people with disabilities and their carers, resulting in serious uncertainties about the reliability and validity of the proposed Impairment Tables as well as over 100 proposed amendments since the bill was guillotined through the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I wish to respond to a number of points made by honourable senators from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in the course of the second reading debate. SPEECH.PARA: First, it ought to be noted that consultations on this Bill began in 1984 and have gone on continually ever since. One wonders what kind of consultation people want. In the course of the preparations of the disability task force in particular the consultations were long and exhaustive. It just cannot be said that consultation here has been inadequate. What can be said, of course, is that some groups do not like everything that is in the Bill.

The fact that the Australian Council of Social Service in particular would not be happy with some aspects of this Bill is hardly surprising given that ACOSS has opposed the Newstart and JSA initiatives involving training. I am not all that shocked by the attitude of the Opposition in claiming that there was inadequate consultation, and this is proved by the number of amendments. The person who has taken this to by far the greatest lengths has been Senator Lees.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're all wrong and you're all right!

I have an extraordinary press release here from Senator Lees which refers to 103 amendments. From my last count there are about 116. This is apparently an example of inadequate consultation.

The idea that this is some sleight of hand trick pulled out of a hat at the last minute is absolute rubbish. It is also a pretty big insult to those people who worked in the disability task force for as long as they did and as effectively as they did to produce what is a major change in the way that we administer this policy in Australia; a major change from the way it has been done in the past; and, in my view, a change for the better.

To go through some other points raised during the debate, both Senator Alston and I think Senator Patterson raised the question of reviewing all existing clients. To attempt to do that would be a massive exercise.
Senator Patterson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston did but Senator Patterson may not have. If I have taken Senator Patterson's name in vain, I apologise. To try to review all existing clients would be an exercise that no government would undertake. SPEECH.PARA: Senator West interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what he said, but there has been a bit of a problem with Mr Tim Fischer over that. But we will talk about that tomorrow. I think that we can dismiss any claim that all existing cases ought to be reviewed.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable senators have raised problems with impairment tables. These are worth commenting on. I have never claimed that impairment tables are perfect instruments. However, it is the case that there must be a basis for payment, a basis which will enable all Australian residents to be assessed in the same way. The impairment tables are the only way that I know of doing that assessment. These impairment tables have been in existence for some years; they are not brand new instruments. Most have been fully tested, with only one or two exceptions. Over time, I think they have proven to be the only way to go.

There is no suggestion that impairment is the same as incapacity to work. I would have thought, particularly in reference to what Senator Lees has had to say in this debate, that was fairly obvious from the legislation. There is a two-stage process here. The first hurdle to jump is related to the 20 per cent impairment; then we look at those incapacity to work factors. They take into account a range of non-medical issues, but only after the impairment test has been passed. That is where a person's skills, literacy problems or whatever will be taken into account to determine the sort of training that might be appropriate. For those aged 55 years and over, a number of local factors can be taken into account. That is not a significant concession, given that more than 40 per cent of the invalid pension grants last year were made to those aged 55 years and over.

The impairment tables will be monitored very carefully during the next 12 months. We will involve medical experts from outside the Public Service as well as within. We will involve experts in the field of rehabilitation and we will look at where those impairment tables stand after that time.

In the course of her contribution Senator Lees raised the question of a reduction in payments for those who are aged under 21 years. The common allowance structure was put in place to remove any incentive for young persons, in this case those with disabilities, to attempt to reduce their employment potential which would allow them to get onto a pension very early. In so many cases, those people stay on the pension for a very long time. That long term dependency was, at least in part, the reason behind this legislation in the first place. So many of the groups who represent the disabled, and the disabled people themselves, mentioned the problem of the very young getting a pension very early. There being no training, no rehabilitation, available for them, they stay on those payments for very long periods. I do not really believe that any sensible government would have a choice but to do as we have done.

Senator Patterson said that she did not claim that we should review all existing pensioners. She certainly did say that we should focus more on existing pensioners. I think that this point, at least in part, comes from the suggestion that there will not be any big cut in the rate of increase in grants of the new payment as against the old. I am not sure that the purpose of this part of the legislation was just to cut the rate of increase of the pension. If people can pass what the Parliament of Australia can agree upon as the relevant test, they ought to get this payment or any other. It is not a matter of any government being in a position to say that any rate of increase is in some way wrong.

However, the Government certainly does acknowledge that the rate of increase over the past few years has been there because so many non-medical factors were being taken into account. That is why the 20 per cent impairment test was introduced. A medical test has to be passed, not a language skill test or so many of the other factors which had been taken into account in a threshold way in determining eligibility for the old invalid pension. The focus on these new entrants will be on links to rehabilitation and training. I would have thought that was a very important reform. I did not hear all of Senator Walters's contribution, but I do not think that she added anything new to the points that were made.

The Opposition's general view was that in some way these reforms are too soft, that they do not tighten up eligibility enough and that we need to do more to maximise the work potential of people. That is probably fair evidence that we have got the legislation about right. With ACOSS telling us that the provisions in the legislation are too hard and the Opposition telling us that they are not hard enough, the legislation is probably somewhere near right.

In concluding this debate, I should say that I have been very pleased indeed with the attitude taken by so many groups representing the disabled who have supported the thrust of this legislation. They know this legislation will mean that training and rehabilitation will become available as a matter of routine to a whole class of people to whom it has been denied in the past and that much of the long term dependence on the old invalid pension system need not necessarily be the same for many entrants in the new system. Instead, there will be real hope that their work force potential will be realised. That can be of real benefit not only to them but to the whole of Australia.

Because of my interest and background, having taught at the Lincoln Institute, where there are speech pathologists, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, et cetera, I gave these people the tables to look at, and they were horrified. The orthoptists looked at the vision section. These people, unlike many medical practitioners in rehabilitative medicine, have been trained in assessment of function. Basically, many of them assess people's function and ability to work, the very thing that we need to be doing to assess whether people should be eligible for a disability pension.

A number of experts in the allied health professions could have made a considerable contribution. I have been told by departmental officers that an ongoing assessment is to be made of these tables, and hopefully it will be. But when I asked at the hearing of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs which public and private medical welfare and other groups were consulted during the formulation of the impairment tables, I was told by the Government:

Consultations have been held with a number of experts in the rehabilitation field. The process was, however, essentially one of refinement rather than formulation and . . . was based on experience gained from utilisation of the current tables together with outcomes of reliability and validity tests.
Understandably, I considered that this answer was inadequate and asked the question again. This time I was told:

The tables evolved over a period of three and a half years. Modifications have been made over this time. In this evolutionary process, various experts have been consulted about aspects of impairment and disability assessment. These have included Dr Robert Oakshott, Professor Dennis Smith, Dr Bruce Kinlock, Director, Rehabilitation at the Rehabilitation Hospital in Melbourne.

I think the second answer indicates a narrow and inadequate level of consultation in regard to these important impairment tables. As I said, a number of allied health professionals have expressed to me their concern about the validity and reliability of these tables. These are people in the business of functional assessment. Some of them have claimed that the publication of the American Medical Association, Guide to the Evaluation of Medical Impairment, upon which these tables are based, has been widely discredited as a means for measuring functional capacity resulting from disability. That is the professional opinion of one group of people. It would have been good to have had those sorts of consultations and to have been able to evaluate whether this is the best impairment table.

It is worth noting that before a ball has even been bowled there have been 12 Government amendments to the impairment tables, which is an indication of the Government's lack of confidence in these ill-prepared tables. It can be gauged from the Minister's promises that anyone with an impairment level of between 10 per cent and 20 per cent can be reassessed while a social security advisory council working party will formally monitor the operation of the tables over the next 12 months.

It is worth noting the extent of the changes that have been made to this Bill since it passed through the House of Representatives, after which the Government belatedly realised that it would not be able to get away with not consulting with the various groups representing people with disabilities. These changes include the power to direct clients to seek medical treatment being removed and all penalties and deferment periods for failing to undertake rehabilitation or training being removed. Provision has been made for the sufferers of recurring, chronic illnesses to reapply for sickness allowance before the end of the disqualifying period. Incentive allowance will continue to be paid to current recipients who enter employment but then return to benefit. Special provisions were inserted to ensure that people who are undergoing drug and alcohol related treatment are not disadvantaged by the 12-month sickness allowance time limit. Transitional provisions were inserted so that the sickness allowees would not be disadvantaged when an extant application is being considered by the Department of Social Security. Formal recognition has been given in the legislation to the provision of rehabilitation and training to pensioner recipients as well as rehabilitation to sickness allowees.

I do not think that we can consider those to be minor changes. I am not saying that I do not agree with those changes, but it seems to me that the Government could have consulted much more widely. Hopefully, as the Department has promised, the consultation on the tables will continue so that we can iron out the problems and so that groups such as those at the Lincoln Institute, the Curtin University and Cumberland will be consulted. There is a wealth of experience in the people of those three institutions, whose primary role in teaching and research is in functional assessment. I hope that these tables will be given to them and that their critical and constructive comments can be taken into account.

Originally, the legislation referred to award wages or those wages that the secretary had deemed reasonable. This caused a furore, as the Victorian Trades and Labour Council believed that the legislation would allow the payment of below award wages to people with disabilities.

The Bill was then changed on 15 August to include the reference to award wages. On 23 August these amendments were amended again to take out the reference to award wages. The reference to award wages has now been reinserted.

The Opposition will not be supporting the Government's amendment on the grounds that the term `award wages' is not an appropriate term which represents the reward that is provided to workers as payment for their labour. A large number of workers are not paid award wages; these include the self-employed, people who operate franchises and people who work as subcontractors. The term `award wages' is an industrial relations term only. It refers to the wages that are paid to a person as set out in an award which has been ratified by an industrial relations tribunal.

Admittedly, the majority of workers are now covered by awards-the majority, but not all. I include in the group `not all' those people who are self-employed. Whether people will continue to have their wages and conditions set out in an award is an industrial relations matter. With the onset of enterprise bargaining-supported now, I might say, by both sides of politics-it is possible that in the future the wages of far fewer workers will be set down in awards than is the case today.

The reason for this amendment and the original clause in this Bill was to refer to what is normally considered to be 30 hours worth of work in the mainstream work force. The Opposition believes that the original clause reflected the fact that some people are not covered by awards provided for them. Those people have now been excluded from this clause due to the hankerings of the trade union movement. The Opposition does not support the concept of people being paid below award wages but, rather, being paid reasonably for their labour. Amendment 9 entitles a claimant to a further assessment by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service where they are originally assessed as having an impairment of less than 20 per cent. As with previous amendments, this amendment seeks to clarify the difference between `impairment' and `incapacity' for the purpose of eligibility for the pension. I stress, as I did in my speech in the second reading debate, that inability on the part of the Government to understand the difference is at the heart of the problems that the Australian Democrats have with this legislation.

Amendments 10 and 11 relate to payments for young people with disabilities. I acknowledge the Minister's continuing reference to equating all young people's support at a very low level. We believe, in this case in particular, that it is not appropriate. We have consistently rejected the Government's program of bringing all of these benefits down into line. All income support measures for young people are now reduced to the point where they are below the poverty line. We reject this further step to similarly cut the levels of income for young people with disabilities.

I do not agree with what the Minister said earlier-that somehow we will be encouraging young people to take up a pension. Considering the very tight requirements that will now be in place relating to the impairment tables, and only the impairment tables, I think it is really a nonsense to suggest that somehow we need this move by the Government to ensure that young people do not get on to the pension and stay there.

The Government has introduced a number of measures that will now give young people the opportunity to undertake rehabilitation and training if they are on the pension. I do not agree at all with the Government's reasonings for reducing the payments to young people. The payments have been reduced to the point where many parents have said that they will find it extremely difficult to make ends meet, considering the additional costs they are forced to meet for a young person with a disability.

The groups which provide accommodation for young people rely on part pension for being paid. Is the Government looking at any additional support for these organisations which provide young people with accommodation? These organisations will now find that a person over 21 will be able to pay the full rate. But, as the pensions of young people have been cut-who, I must stress, cost the same to feed, clothe and look after-they will now not be able to keep contributing. Those people coming onto the pension will now be paying less for their accommodation. Has the Government looked at the possibility of supporting these organisations by making up the difference?

Senator Lees knows about the 19 per cent being rounded up. We did include a gynaecological table. There is clearer treatment of the use of `pain'. If a person is rated as between 10 per cent and 20 per cent, they can get that reassessment, as well as retaining full appeal rights. A body has been established to monitor these tables, as we have already mentioned.

On Senator Lees's comments about the common youth allowance structure, the important point to note is that nobody gets cut. We are talking about new entrants. No-one on a payment gets cut; therefore, no-one's circumstances are altered by this legislation.

There are a number of ways in which the disability support payment for 16-year-olds to 20-year-olds will differ from the common youth allowance. They are subject to the more generous pension, income and assets tests; 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds will not be subject to parental income and assets testing; and 16 year-olds and 17 year-olds who are unable to live with their parents due to their medical condition will receive a higher independent rate applicable to their age. There are a number of differences, all of which are on the right side for those who are in this position. There are more generous provisions available to young recipients in institutions.

As to those who provide accommodation, I will have to check with my colleague Mr Howe on what arrangements are being made. They are also subject to some discussions with the States. I am not certain where that is up to, but I am happy to find out.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, as announced by the Treasurer in the 1991-92 Budget, this Bill will amend the wholesale sales tax law to change the current exemptions for certain goods and motor vehicles for use by people with disabilities.

The Government has already made decisions on the Industry Commission Report on Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities. The Bill implements the majority of the Industry Commission proposals relating to sales tax. It also provides additional exemptions and concessions beyond those recommended by the Commission.
These measures demonstrate the Government's concern that the taxation treatment of goods for use by people with disabilities should be both equitable and responsible.
Goods used in modifications of motor vehicles

Under the current sales tax law, exemption is only available for goods used to modify a motor vehicle to adapt it for driving by a person suffering from a physical disability. The Bill will significantly widen this exemption to include goods used to modify new or second-hand motor vehicles to transport a person suffering from a physical disability.
This exemption will assist those who are required to modify their vehicles solely for the purpose of transporting a family member, relative or friend who is suffering from a physical disability.
This important new exemption was not included in the Industry Commission proposals.
Exemption for certain new motor vehicles

The Bill will place a limit on the sales tax exemptions available for new motor vehicles for use by certain defence force veterans and other people with specific disabilities. The current exemptions are completely open-ended, and those most able to afford expensive new motor vehicles are able to derive greater benefits than those with less income.
The Bill will ensure greater equity in this area by providing that a maximum sales tax benefit (or ``cap'') will apply to all new vehicles purchased under these exemptions.

Sales tax exemption will be limited to motor vehicles with a wholesale sale value equal to or less than the current ``luxury'' motor vehicle sale value threshold of $30,505. This corresponds to a retail list price of $45,462, and is the amount above which sales tax on motor vehicles is now payable at 30%.

Where the sale value of the vehicle exceeds the threshold, the vehicle will be taxable. However, tax will be payable on a reduced sale value. This will produce a benefit equal to the amount of sales tax that would have been payable if the vehicle had been priced on the threshold.
This is more generous than the Industry Commission proposal, under which vehicles above the threshold would have been fully taxable.
Commencement
The changes made by the Bill will apply to all taxable dealings that occur after 3.00 pm standard time, 20 August, 1991.
The net cost of the proposed changes will be $3m for 1991-92 and $3.5m in a full year.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight in the adjournment debate on a matter concerning a Mr and Mrs Hardwick, who live in the Bendigo area of Victoria. North West Country Credit propose to put the Sheriff in possession of their property tomorrow. The history is a long one. The property comprises 138 acres, of which 38 acres are used for accommodation for approximately 72 people. It is being used as an environmental education centre. Part of the property can be subdivided into a small farm of 100 acres and the 38 acres would be zoned for business. The couple intends to put it into a trust so that it may remain a study centre.

SPEECH.PARA: The couple got into difficulties some years ago when a loan, which currently stands at $164,000, was taken out at an interest rate of 15 per cent. The rate they are being charged now is 22 per cent, making it almost a certainty that financial difficulties will arise.

The purpose of my putting this case on the record is not to ask that that be forgiven or that substantial changes be made, but simply to ask that a proposal which was put to North West Country Credit this afternoon by the firm of Fisher Dowell and Co Pty Ltd be given due consideration by the board. From a superficial assessment, admittedly, of the figures, the proposal deserves consideration.

The proposal basically is that North West and the Hardwicks sell the farm land in lot B, some 100 acres, by private sale as soon as practicable to reduce the debt; that North West allow the Hardwicks to remain in occupation of the study centre-that is lot A-until 30 January 1992 based on the first mortgage already in place; and that the Hardwicks continue with efforts to re-finance or sell to the trust the study centre and so pay back North West.

The Hardwicks have forward bookings which will generate a net income of over $12,000 by 30 November 1991 and a very real likelihood of achieving better results if allowed to trade without interruption. In fact, North West might be asked if it is prepared to reduce the interest rate to a more realistic current market rate than the Hardwicks are currently being forced to pay. That would further improve the possibility of the rescue being successful.

I thought I should put this proposal on record because I have been told-only just 15 minutes ago-by the Manager of North West Country Credit that they are not disposed to defer the Sheriff going into possession of the property; that, in its opinion, the Hardwicks need to be put out of the property. The Hardwicks have worked hard to develop the property over a period of 18 years and I believe that the proposal that has been put forward deserves a chance to be looked at carefully and sympathetically. I think we are at a period in the history of our nation, particularly in Victoria, where many people are fighting for survival. Rather than push them down and deprive them of their life earnings and savings, we should do everything possible to assist them to survive. The figures I have been supplied with and which I have seen this afternoon-I cannot vouch for them of course-indicate a positive net asset value exceeding $90,000. In that position, one does not put people out of an enterprise that is still functioning, however poorly. I believe that the board of North West Country Credit should look very carefully at the proposal being put to it and should give it sympathetic consideration.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Access of Courts to Cabinet Documents

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter which I hope to speak about at greater length later, but which is important enough to raise tonight, is a decision of the Federal Court-and a very strong Federal Court it was last week-which said that it was proper that the legal advisers of a litigant be allowed to look at Cabinet notebooks. I think there is a lot to be concerned about in that judgment, and it is a matter that we as a Parliament will have to address.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not suggesting for one minute that the judiciary is doing this, but if the judiciary were to take over what is, in fact, the proper role of the legislature-which is, as it were, to oversee the Executive-that would be an unhappy situation. The Executive is responsible to the legislature, not to the judiciary. It must be said that perhaps we as legislators-as parliamentarians-have not brought the Executive to account as efficiently as we should. But that, it seems to me, is a matter where the Parliament-the legislature-has to raise its game rather than the courts coming in and substituting for it.

A proper balance of power-a proper separation of the three functions of government-involves a situation where the three of them reserve themselves to the limits that are properly set so that good government overall can take place. I have not read the judgment, and I am not suggesting that in this case it has, but if it were to lead to a situation where not only did the judiciary go into the Cabinet room more often to see what went on there but also it allowed the Cabinet discussions to be made patent to legal advisers, then a very difficult situation for the proper balance of power would have been reached.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 August 1991:

(3) Did the Minister's disabilities consultant accompany the Minister on his September/October 1990 European trip.

(5) If the prime purpose of the party's trip to Europe was to discuss and sign social security agreements, for what reason did the Minister's disabilities consultant accompany the party and why did the consultant travel at public expense.
(6) Did the department incur any expense for the consultant's trip to Europe; if so, what are any or all of the details of any and all of the costs incurred.
(7) Of those costs incurred, what expenses have since been determined by the consultant to have been of a personal nature and have since been requited.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The answer to this question was provided in answer to a question placed on notice by the honourable Senator at Senate Estimates Committee C on 16 April 1991. The answer is contained in `Estimates Committee C, Additional Information Received, Volume 1' of May 1991--pages 36-37.

(2) The answer to this question was provided in answer to a question placed on notice by the honourable Senator at Senate Estimates Committee C on 16 April 1991. The answer is contained in `Estimates Committee C, Additional Information Received, Volume 1' of May 1991 pages 36-37.

(3) The answer to this question was provided in response to a question placed on notice by the honourable Senator at Senate Estimates Committee D on 18 April 1991. The answer is contained in `Estimates Committee D, Additional Information Received, Volume 2' of June 1991--pages 215- 229.

(4) The answer to this question was provided in response to a question placed on notice by the honourable Senator at Senate Estimates D on 18 April 1991. The answer is contained in `Estimates Committee D, Additional Information Received, Volume 2' of June 1991--pages 215-229.

(5) It is customary for a staff member or consultant to accompany Ministers on visits overseas.
